episodes.original_body:
Case: Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020
Client: Estate of Betty Prince

Date: 10/27/2021
User: Stuttle
Note: "Recvd Mr. Prince's Statement via email from Jayme Larrison (he is not computer savvy):
 

 
To whom it may concern:

Please find below the accounts of the day in question.

Before we left the house to arrive at the set appointment at Norton's hospital in Louisville Ky.  I Robert Prince assisted my wife Betty Prince to bath and dress. I walked beside her aiding her from the house to my car. After I drove 60+ miles to Norton's Hospital, I parked in the guest parking lot. Betty Prince was unable to walk into the facility without help. I Robert Prince walked beside her for stability and direction. When we entered the hospital we both completed the Covid screening procedures, which was a temperature check and answered a few questions. Betty stood during this activity while holding to my arm.  Betty walked to the admitting room with my help. When we reached the registration office Betty had become weaker, and her pace and endurance had lessened and her breathing was shallower and labored.

Upon arrival in the waiting room of the registration office, Betty was seated in a chair. After a shot interval the office employee called her name and I helped her stand. As was previously stated Betty was weak and short of breath. When Betty and myself reached the door way I was told because of the the regulation due to Covid I could not enter the office area.  No assistance was offer to the patient such as a wheel chair a walker or direct personal help.

After a short period of time the office staff employee opened the door Betty was following her. Again no assistance to ensure Betty's safety was offered.  As Betty  stepped into the waiting room she fell backwards hitting her head on the floor which resulted in a large cut in the back of her head .I Robert Prince immediately went to her . Betty was laying on her back in a puddle of blood. At that point no one offered any assistance in addressing her injury. nor was there anyone monitoring her vitals. I Robert Prince asked a staff member to give me a towel. when I received the towel I put pressure on the area on her head which was bleeding. Two call were made to the ER . After 10 minutes two medical staff came and transported Betty Prince to the ER. Nine stiches were put in her head, a CT Scam revealed  active bleeding in her brain. Betty was admitted to the hospital and placed in the ICU.  After thirty six hours she was placed in a private room. Betty remained in the private room for an additional  thirty six hours. Betty then was released.  An appointment was made to return in two weeks to have a CT scam to check her progress.

These are the events to best of my knowledge which occured on the day in question

If you have any additional questions please contact me

Sincerely

Robert Prince"
episodes.natural_language:
On October 27, 2021, the Estate of Betty Prince received an email statement from Robert Prince, forwarded by Jayme Larrison, who is not computer savvy. The statement details the events of the day in question regarding Betty Prince. Robert explains that before leaving the house to go to Norton’s Hospital in Louisville, Kentucky, he assisted Betty with bathing and dressing, and walked beside her from the house to his car. They then drove more than 60 miles to Norton’s Hospital and parked in the guest parking lot. Betty was unable to walk into the facility without help, so Robert walked beside her for stability and direction. Upon entering the hospital, they both completed Covid screening procedures, including a temperature check and answering a few questions, with Betty standing during the screening while holding Robert’s arm. Betty then walked to the admitting area with his assistance. 

When they reached the registration office, Betty had become weaker, with her pace and endurance diminished and her breathing shallower and more labored. In the waiting room of the registration area, Betty was seated in a chair. After a short interval, the office employee called her name and Robert helped her stand. Betty remained weak and short of breath. As they approached the doorway, Robert was told that, due to Covid regulations, he could not enter the office area, and no assistance or safety aids (such as a wheelchair, walker, or direct personal help) were offered to the patient. After a short period, the office staff member opened the door and Betty followed, but again no assistance to ensure her safety was provided. 

As Betty stepped into the waiting room, she fell backward and hit her head on the floor, resulting in a large cut to the back of her head. Robert Prince immediately went to her side; she was lying on her back in a puddle of blood. At that time, no one offered assistance to address her injury, nor was anyone monitoring her vitals. Robert asked a staff member for a towel, and after receiving it he applied pressure to the bleeding area on her head. Two calls were made to the ER. After about 10 minutes, two medical staff arrived and transported Betty Prince to the ER. She received nine stitches in her head, and a CT scan revealed active bleeding in her brain. Betty was admitted to the hospital and placed in the Intensive Care Unit. After thirty-six hours she was moved to a private room, where she remained for an additional thirty-six hours before being released. An appointment was scheduled to return in two weeks for another CT scan to monitor her progress. 

These are the events to the best of my knowledge that occurred on the day in question. If you have any additional questions, please contact me. 

Sincerely,
Robert Prince

episodes.natural_language:
The Estate of Betty Prince case began with a return call after we received RM from the client. He had received the Probate Inventory and wanted to make sure he completed it properly as No Assets. I advised that this is proper since there has been settlement on the claim as of yet.

He also asked about the status. I advised that DC is collecting MRs and that can take 2 months or so, and that we will update him once they have received everything.

He mentioned that they had received a No Records Notice from CareTenders. He advised CareTenders should have all kinds of records since they were Betty's home care providers and came out routinely and even helped get her medical hospital bed.

He is a happy camper at the moment.

episodes.original_body:
Case: Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020
Client: Estate of Betty Prince

Recvd Call from Husband Robert - He was able to locate a calendar provided by Betty's At Home Care Provider - Kindred At Home not CareTenders - Also he mentioned Betty was inpatient for 7 days/7 nights @ Madisonville Hospital without Dialysis due to the risk - Madisonville sent Betty to Norton Hospital for Dialysis treatment where they could use less pressure and 'pull' longer to lower the risk - Unfortunately, according to Robert Norton provided regular Dialysis causing Betty's Heart to drop to 76 where Madisonville always stopped at 100... He just thought we should be aware.
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on July 14, 2020 with the Estate of Betty Prince. The call came from Betty Prince’s husband, Robert. He reported that he had located a calendar provided by Betty’s at-home care provider—Kindred At Home, not CareTenders. He also noted that Betty had been inpatient for 7 days/7 nights at Madisonville Hospital without dialysis due to the risk. Madisonville sent Betty to Norton Hospital for dialysis treatment, where they could use less pressure and “pull” longer to lower the risk.

According to Robert, Norton provided regular dialysis, causing Betty’s heart to drop to 76, whereas Madisonville always stopped at 100. He asked that we be aware of these details.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

Her contact information was listed as ahiggins@ppoalaw.com, (502) 560-9982, and the office address 716 West Main Street, Suite 300, Louisville, Kentucky 40202, with phone P 502.583.9900, fax F 502.587.1927, and the website w ppoalaw.com.

The message includes a confidentiality disclaimer stating: “This e-mail message from the law firm of Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC is for the sole use of the intended recipient(s) and may contain confidential and privileged information. It should not be copied or forwarded to any unauthorized persons. If you are not the intended recipient, please contact the sender by reply e-mail (or call 502.583.9900) to advise us of thttp://ppoalaw.comroy all copies of the original message.”

The forwarded content ends with the signature line: “-- Aaron Whaley Whaley Law Firm 712 Lyndon Ln Louisville, KY 40222 502-583-4022.”

Case: Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020. Client: Estate of Betty Prince.

In this estate matter, an email thread regarding discovery in Prince v. Norton Hospitals was forwarded on July 29, 2022. An email from Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm to Sarena Tuttle notified her that medical discovery production had been added to the Dropbox folder related to Prince v. Norton Hospitals. The message stated that a link, provided in a previous email, grants access to the medical and billing records received regarding Betty Prince, and it invited any questions or issues and offered to be contacted for assistance.

The forwarded message was originated by Anthony Luken, a paralegal at Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC, and was dated Friday, July 29, 2022, at 1:19 PM. In that message, Luken advised counsel that medical discovery production had been moved to a Dropbox folder and would be accessible to anyone with the link. He indicated that the folder contains medical and billing records related to Betty Prince and noted that new discovery would be added to this digital space with notification of arrival. He provided the following Dropbox link: https://www.dropbox.com/sh/7tu659sm88fbd4y/AAB2-CQY3uiD8CaQZWRl-qVya?dl=0. Luken also offered his contact information: he was the paralegal to Joseph Effinger, Matthew Piekarski, Bobby Whitmer, and Ryan Nafziger; telephone number 502-560-9962; fax number 502-587-1927; mailing address 716 West Main Street, Suite 300, Louisville, Kentucky 40202; main office phone 502-583-9900 and fax 502-587-1927; and the firm’s website at w ppoalaw.com. His email signature was followed by a confidentiality notice stating that the email from Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC is for the sole use of the intended recipient(s) and may contain confidential and privileged information, and should not be copied or forwarded to unauthorized persons; if the recipient is not the intended one, they should contact the sender and destroy all copies of the original message.

In addition to the July 29, 2022 message, the thread also contains the earlier email from Anthony Luken dated Tuesday, June 28, 2022 at 7:24 PM to Aaron Whaley, with the subject Prince v. Norton Hospitals- Discovery Production Dropbox Link. In that message, Luken explained that discovery production sharing had shifted to electronic means via Dropbox and that physical CDs containing discovery production would no longer be sent, except for radiology discs. He provided the same principle about access to medical and billing records for Betty Prince and stated that new discovery would be added to the digital space and that recipients would be notified of its arrival. The Dropbox link accompanying this message was https://www.dropbox.com/sh/7tu659sm88fbd4y/AAB2-CQY3uiD8CaQZWRl-qVya?dl=0. Luken again signed as Paralegal to Joseph Effinger, Matthew Piekarski, Bobby Whitmer, and Ryan Nafziger with the same contact details listed above, followed by the Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC confidentiality notice.

The chain ends with the standard footer information: Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, phone 502-583-4022. The forwarded correspondence includes the confidentiality and privileged information notices typical of the law firms involved, including references to the maps link text “Phttps://www.google.com/maps/search/716” appearing in the footer and to the firm name Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC.

episodes.original_body:
Case: Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020
Client: Estate of Betty Prince

Recvd Client VM - Returned his call - He advised he received a 'text' requesting information but he is not sure what is being requested - I do not see any 'text' or notes regarding this - advised will reach out to Assoc Franklin and see if he needs anything - Robert asked that if we need anything in writing to call him & go over on the phone while we write for him - Advised that would be fine moving forward - He again expressed his belief that Norton's killed his wife - After S/F she was being treated at Kings' Daughter for Dialysis to remove fluid - Kings' Daughter was not able to pull soft enough & was causing a strain on her heart - They sent her back to Norton's where the orders for a slow, soft pull was ignored and her pressure dropped extremely low - they unhooked her from the machine around 7pm - She had issues breathing and finally passed away at 4am - Client is wanting this to be included in the current case - Advised I would reach out to Assoc and make sure he is aware. #cc
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on July 14, 2020 with the Estate of Betty Prince regarding matters in the case. The client left a voicemail and returned his call, saying he had received a “text” requesting information, but he is not sure what is being requested. I do not see any text or notes regarding this. He said he would reach out to Associate Franklin to see if he needs anything. Robert asked that, if we need anything in writing, we call him and go over it on the phone while we write for him, and I advised that would be fine moving forward.

He again expressed his belief that Norton’s killed his wife. After S/F she was being treated at Kings’ Daughter for dialysis to remove fluid. Kings’ Daughter was not able to pull soft enough and was causing a strain on her heart. They sent her back to Norton's where the orders for a slow, soft pull were ignored and her pressure dropped extremely low. They unhooked her from the machine around 7 p.m. She had trouble breathing and ultimately died at 4 a.m. The client wants this to be included in the current case. I advised I would reach out to Associate and make sure he is aware. #cc
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Matthew Piekarski, Joseph Effinger, and Ryan Nafziger, with Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon CC’d, forwarding the client’s Responses to Norton Hospital’s Interrogatories and Request for Production of Documents. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us.” Her message originated from The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and included her direct line (502) 357-9971, office line (502) 583-4022 ext. 104, and her email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, noting the new email address in the signature. The forwarded email also contained the standard confidentiality disclaimer identifying the email as intended for the recipients and instructing that any unauthorized use should be avoided.

Later, at 11:46 a.m. that same day, Joseph M. Effinger, Esq., of Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, LLP, forwarded the prior message to Andrea Higgins. Effinger’s signature listed his firm’s contact information: 716 West Main Street, Suite 300, Louisville, KY 40202; telephone (502) 583-9900; facsimile (502) 587-1927. The forwarded message again bore the firm’s confidentiality disclaimer.

At 4:01 p.m. on July 21, 2023, Andrea L. Higgins, the Legal Assistant to Joseph M. Effinger, Matthew A. Piekarski, Ryan D. Nafziger, and Blake Gerstner, sent an email to Sarena Tuttle. The email also reproduced the confidentiality notice customary to correspondence from Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC, indicating the message is for the sole use of the intended recipients and should not be copied or forwarded to unauthorized persons, with instructions to contact the sender if the message was received in error and to destroy all copies.

Additionally, Sarena Tuttle’s original email carried the firm’s standard letterhead and disclaimers, including the note to contact the sender if not the intended recipient and the instruction to destroy any copies if misdirected. The correspondence reflects a coordinated effort among the lawyers and staff at The Whaley Law Firm and Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC to obtain the plaintiff’s executed Medical and Social Security authorizations as part of the discovery responses in the 21-CI-003798 matter.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020. Client: Estate of Betty Prince. Re: FW: 21-CI-003798 Robert Prince v Norton Hospital - PL Resp to Disc Req.

On July 21, 2023, in the matter 21-CI-003798 Robert Prince v Norton Hospital, the estate plaintiff represented as the Estate of Betty Prince exchanged a series of emails concerning the Plaintiff’s responses to Norton Hospital’s discovery requests (Interrogatories and Request for Production of Documents). The communications involved counsel from Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC, and The Whaley Law Firm, with accompanying confidentiality notices typical of the firms’ emails.

At 11:23 AM, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Matthew Piekarski, Joseph Effinger, and Ryan Nafziger, with Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon copied, stating: “Good afternoon Mr. Nafziger, Please find attached our client’s Responses to Norton Hospital’s Interrogatories and Request for Production of Documents. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us.” The message announced the attached responses and included the standard confidentiality disclaimer typical of The Whaley Law Firm’s correspondence. The sender’s signature block also provided Sarena’s contact information and noted that this was her new email address.

Earlier, at 11:46 AM, Joseph M. Effinger, Esq., of Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, forwarded the aforementioned message to Andrea Higgins, Esq., at the law firm PPOA, including the subject line “FW: 21-CI-003798 Robert Prince v Norton Hospital - PL Resp to Disc Req.” The forwarded email chain carried the relevant attachments and the standard firm disclaimer.

At approximately 12:01 PM, Andrea L. Higgins, Legal Assistant to Joseph M. Effinger, responded to Sarena, asking: “Sarena, Please provide the Plaintiff’s executed Medical and Social Security authorizations as indicated in the Responses to Defendant’s discovery requests.” This message included the PPOA firm’s confidentiality disclaimer and the sender’s contact information.

Following that, at 12:55 PM, Sarena Tuttle replied to Andrea Higgins: “Good afternoon Andrea, Mr. Prince is not able to use electronic methods to receive or execute documents. The Authorizations/Releases have been forwarded to Mr. Prince via USPS for execution and will be supplemented upon receipt.” The reply again carried The Whaley Law Firm’s standard confidentiality notice and Sarena’s contact details, including her title as Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, and noting her new email address.

Finally, at 4:57 PM (16:57:30 UTC), Andrea Higgins replied with a brief confirmation: “Okay. Thank you.” This concluding message likewise included the PPOA and firm disclaimer blocks and the sender’s signature.

Signatures and contact details appeared consistently in the messages. The Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC messages carried the firm’s address at 716 West Main Street, Suite 300, Louisville, Kentucky 40202, with telephone and fax numbers, and their standard confidentiality disclaimer. The Whaley Law Firm messages carried their own address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct line and main line numbers, the new email address for Sarena Tuttle, and the same confidentiality language.

episodes.natural_language:
This narrative summarizes the correspondence in the Estate of Betty Prince’s case (Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020) regarding the matter 21-CI-003798, Robert Prince v Norton Hospital, specifically the Plaintiff’s Responses to the Defendant’s discovery requests and the related medical and social security authorizations.

On July 21, 2023, at 11:23 a.m., Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Andrea L. Higgins at Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC, with copies to Joseph Effinger and Ryan Nafziger and with Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon CC’d. The message stated that attached were the client’s Responses to Norton Hospital’s Interrogatories and Request for Production of Documents, and it included Sarena’s signature and her contact information, noting her new email address. The email also contained the standard confidentiality notice typical of correspondence from PPOA.

Earlier that same morning, at 11:46 a.m., Joseph M. Effinger, Esq., on behalf of Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, forwarded the email chain to Andrea Higgins (the Legal Assistant to several PPOA attorneys) at PPOA, including the firm’s contact information and reiterating the message thread.

At approximately 12:01 p.m. on July 21, 2023, Andrea Higgins responded, notifying Sarena that the Plaintiff’s executed Medical and Social Security authorizations were to be provided as indicated in the discovery responses. Higgins’s message included her own contact details and the firm’s standard confidentiality disclaimer.

Around 12:55 p.m., Sarena Tuttle replied that Mr. Prince is not able to receive or execute documents electronically. The Authorizations/Releases had been forwarded to Mr. Prince via USPS for execution and would be supplemented upon receipt. Her message also reiterated her role and provided her contact information, including the note to use her new email address.

Approximately two minutes later, at 12:57 p.m., Andrea Higgins replied with, “Sarena, Please provide the Plaintiff’s executed Medical and Social Security authorizations as indicated in the Responses to Defendant’s discovery requests,” followed by her signature block and the firm’s confidentiality notice.

The thread continued with the same day’s exchanges, including the earlier messages from Sarena and the PPOA staff, which collectively documented the process and expectations regarding the plaintiff’s execution of the requested authorizations.

Finally, on August 2, 2023, at 10:44 a.m., Sarena Tuttle sent another email to Andrea Higgins apologizing for the delayed delivery of the requested authorizations and attaching the documents. She again provided her contact information and noted her new email address. The August 2 message reflects the ongoing effort to obtain the necessary medical and social security authorizations for the case, acknowledging that Mr. Prince could not receive or sign electronically and that the authorizations had been mailed or would be supplemented upon receipt. The message includes the same standard confidentiality notices common to PPOA communications and reiterates the Whaley Law Firm’s representation of the Estate of Betty Prince in the Robert Prince v Norton Hospital matter.

Client: Estate of Betty Prince

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Client VM from yesterday - He received Probate Inventory & wanted to confirm that all he needed to do was sign - Returned his call & advised that his signature is all we needed - He confirmed Inventory Mailed back this morning - Also asked for a rough estimate as to when this might wrap up - again advised that it is hard to tell with such a case - Advised predict Norton will want to settle v trial but no guarantee - Advised will touch base w/AW for more details or call - He stated he would appreciate a call from AW - Sending notice to AW 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: August 02 2023
episodes.natural_language: Initial client contact on August 2, 2023, with Sarena regarding the Estate of Betty Prince (Premise-7-14-2020). The client, the Estate of Betty Prince, reported that he had received a voicemail yesterday stating that he had received the Probate Inventory and wanted to confirm that all he needed to do was sign. Sarena returned his call and advised that his signature is all we needed. He confirmed that the Inventory was mailed back this morning. He also asked for a rough estimate as to when this matter might wrap up; he was advised that it is hard to tell with such a case. He was told that Norton will want to settle v trial but no guarantee. He was advised that we will touch base with AW for more details or a call. He stated that he would appreciate a call from AW. A notice to AW is being sent.

episodes.natural_language:
This narrative chronicles email communications in the Estate-of Betty Prince matter (Estate of Betty Prince, Premise-7-14-2020) related to the case captioned 21-CI-003798, Robert Prince v. Norton Hospital, focused on the Plaintiff’s responses to discovery requests and the processing of medical and social security authorizations.

On Friday, July 21, 2023, at 11:23 AM, Sarena Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Andrea Higgins of Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC, with copies to Matthew Piekarski, Joseph Effinger, and Ryan Nafziger, and with Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon in the CC line. The message stated that attached were the client’s Responses to Norton Hospital’s Interrogatories and Request for Production of Documents. Sarena signed the email with her contact information and noted her new Whaley Law Firm email address.

At 11:46 AM that same day, Joseph Effinger, Esq., forwarded Sarena’s email to Andrea Higgins at PPOA, including his own firm contact details. The forwarded message reiterated the contents of Sarena’s email regarding the discovery responses.

At 12:01 PM, Andrea Higgins replied to Sarena, requesting that the Plaintiff’s executed Medical and Social Security authorizations be provided as indicated in the responses to the defendant’s discovery requests. Andrea’s signature block identified her as Legal Assistant to Joseph M. Effinger, Esq.; Matthew A. Piekarski, Esq.; Ryan D. Nafziger, Esq.; and Blake Gerstner, Esq., with the PPOA contact information and the standard confidentiality disclaimer present at the bottom of the message.

At 12:55 PM, Sarena responded that Mr. Prince is not able to receive or execute documents electronically, and that the Authorizations/Releases had been forwarded to Mr. Prince via USPS for execution and would be supplemented upon receipt. She again signed with her Whaley Law Firm title and updated contact details, including her new email address.

At approximately 12:57 PM, Andrea Higgins replied to Sarena with a brief “Okay. Thank you,” concluding that portion of the exchange.

Several days later, on Friday, August 2, 2023, at 10:45 AM, Sarena wrote again to Andrea Higgins: she apologized for the delayed delivery of the requested authorizations and advised that the authorizations were attached to the email. Her message included her standard signature blocks and newly noted email address.

That same day, the line item “Received. Thank you!” appeared in an email from Andrea Higgins at 14:57:35 UTC, confirming receipt of the attached materials.

Across these exchanges, the correspondence repeatedly bears the standard confidentiality and privileged-information disclaimers typical of the Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC firm signatures, including the firm’s address at 716 West Main Street, Suite 300, Louisville, Kentucky 40202, phone and fax numbers, and the firm’s website. In several messages, Sarena notes the new Whaley Law Firm email address used for professional contact, and the discussions center on providing and timing the Plaintiff’s executed Medical and Social Security authorizations, the Plaintiff’s inability to receive electronic documents, and the transmission of the required authorizations via USPS with supplementation upon receipt.

This case note concerns the Estate of Betty Prince (Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020), the matter Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospital, Inc. in Jefferson Circuit Court, case number 21-CI-003798, and its discovery proceedings.

On August 22, 2023, at 2:31:37 PM Eastern Time, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email titled “Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospital, Inc. (Jefferson Circuit 21-CI-003798) - Discovery” to counsel rnafziger@ppoalaw.com and jeffinger@ppoalaw.com, with BettyPrinceSFZ954585@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com CC’d. In the body of the message, he stated that he had not heard back regarding his previous email and letter, noted that it had been an inordinate amount of time since the discovery requests were propounded and no responses had been received to date, and warned that if responses were not provided very soon he would be forced to file a Motion to Compel. He closed with a request for advice. The email included a standard confidentiality and privilege disclaimer indicating it was intended only for the named recipient, warning that if it was received in error the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm, that no waiver of privilege applied, and advising against using or forwarding the information to anyone not intended to receive it. The message was signed by W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207.

Earlier, on August 17, 2023, at 10:52 AM, Bryce Koon also sent a message with the same recipients and CC, subject “Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospital, Inc. (Jefferson Circuit 21-CI-003798) - Discovery.” In that email, he wrote that they had received responses to their Requests for Admission a while back, but did not appear to have received answers to their Interrogatories or document requests. He noted that he had emailed a letter a few weeks prior regarding this issue but had received no response and requested advice on when they could expect answers to these discovery requests. This email also included the same confidentiality/privilege disclaimer and was signed with the same contact information for W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm.

Case: Estate of Betty Prince – Premise 7-14-2020. Client: Estate of Betty Prince. This file covers discovery communications in Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospital, Inc., Jefferson Circuit Court, case number 21-CI-003798.

On August 28, 2023, Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207) sent an email to Ryan Nafziger and Joseph Effinger (cc’ing BettyPrinceSFZ954585@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com). The subject line was Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospital, Inc. (Jefferson Circuit 21-CI-003798) - Discovery. In the message, Koon stated that they were willing to grant the opposing side additional time to respond to discovery requests but wanted to set the matter on their radar. He also asked to begin scheduling the deposition of an individual referenced in an attached document. The name of this individual was not provided in the email, only the initials “LV.” Koon requested that the recipients identify the person corresponding to those initials and provide several potential deposition dates. He concluded by thanking them and providing his contact information. The message included the standard confidentiality disclaimer common to attorney communications, noting that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney-client privileged or otherwise protected information; if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and not disclose or forward the information.

The exchange also included prior communications from the same two attorneys, dating earlier in August 2023.

On August 22, 2023, at 2:46 p.m., Ryan Nafziger replied to Bryce Koon (and Joseph Effinger) with a cc to BettyPrinceSFZ954585@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com. Nafziger wrote that he was in the process of completing the discovery responses and expected to have them to Koon by the end of the following week. He added that, as he recalled, it had taken nearly a year and a half of emailing to obtain complete responses to their requests, and he appreciated Koon’s patience.

Also on August 22, 2023, at 2:32 p.m., Bryce Koon sent another message to Nafziger and Effinger (cc’ing BettyPrinceSFZ954585@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com). In this message, Koon stated that he had not heard back regarding a previous email and letter. He emphasized that it had been an inordinately long time since the discovery requests were propounded and that no responses had been received to date. He warned that if responses were not provided very soon, he would be forced to file a Motion to Compel. He asked for a response.

Earlier still, on August 17, 2023, at 10:52 a.m., Koon wrote to rnafziger@ppoalaw.com and jeffinger@ppoalaw.com (cc’ing BettyPrinceSFZ954585@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com). He observed that they had received responses to their Requests for Admission some time earlier, but the emails indicated that there had been no responses to Interrogatories or document requests. He noted that he had sent a letter a few weeks prior and had received no response. He asked when they could expect answers to these discovery requests.

In summary, the estate’s counsel faced delayed discovery responses in the Norton Hospital case and sought confirmation of the identity of the deposition subject identified only by initials LV, along with proposed deposition dates. They also communicated a willingness to allow additional time for discovery responses but pressed for timely responses or the possibility of a Motion to Compel if such responses were not forthcoming. The timeline shows a pattern of repeated requests and responses across mid-to-late August 2023, with the most recent August 28 message seeking to move forward with scheduling and identifying the LV individual.

episodes.natural_language:
In the Estate of Betty Prince v Norton Hospital, Inc., Jefferson Circuit Court case 21-CI-003798, discovery has been the subject of ongoing correspondence between the Estate’s counsel and opposing counsel. The case is titled Estate of Betty Prince, with the client listed as the Estate of Betty Prince, and the case file reference includes Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020. The communications flow from mid-August through September 2023 and involve the discovery schedule for Interrogatories, Documents requests, and Requests for Admission, as well as a deposition relevant to an identified individual.

On August 17, 2023, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to opposing counsel (rnavziger@ppoalaw.com and jeffinger@ppoalaw.com, cc’ing BettyPrinceSFZ954585@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com). He noted that the defendants’ Responses for Admission had been received earlier, but no answers had been provided to the Interrogatories or the Document Requests. He indicated that he had emailed a letter a few weeks prior on the matter and asked for an advisory on when answers could be expected. The message included the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer.

Two days later, on August 22, 2023, Bryce Koon sent two separate messages. At 2:32 PM, he again pressed that he had not heard back regarding his previous email and letter. He stated that it had been an inordinate amount of time since the discovery requests were propounded and that no responses had been received to date. He warned that if responses were not forthcoming very soon, he would be forced to file a Motion to Compel. The email carried the same attorney-client privilege disclaimer and contact details for The Whaley Law Firm.

Shortly thereafter, at 2:46 PM the same day, Ryan Nafziger replied. He said he was in the process of completing the discovery requests and would have them to Bryce Koon by the end of the following week. He recalled that it had previously taken almost a year and a-half of emailing to obtain complete responses to their requests and thanked Bryce for his patience. This message also included the standard privilege disclaimer and the familiar contact information for the parties.

On August 28, 2023, Bryce Koon replied to Nafziger and Effinger. He indicated that they were certainly willing to grant additional time for the responses. He asked to proceed with scheduling the deposition for the individual identified in an attached document. He noted that the only information available about this individual appeared to be initials “LV,” and that the name itself was not provided. He requested identification of the individual and suggested providing potential deposition dates. The communication again carried the standard privilege disclaimer and the Whaley Law Firm contact details.

Finally, on September 15, 2023, Bryce Koon sent a follow-up email to Ryan Nafziger and Joseph Effinger, with the subject Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospital, Inc. (Jefferson Circuit 21-CI-003798) - Discovery. He wrote in the body: Good afternoon counsel, it has been a few weeks since their previous discussions. He asked when they could expect responses to the discovery requests and whether the opposing side had identified the individual previously referenced. He signed as W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s Louisville address, telephone, and fax numbers, and again included the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer.

Across all exchanges, the emails repeatedly included standard disclaimers stating the message was intended only for the named recipient and could contain attorney-client privileged or protected information; if received in error, the recipient was instructed to contact The Whaley Law Firm and not to disclose or forward the contents. The correspondences also reflect the ongoing effort to resolve discovery responses, to schedule the deposition for the individual identified only by initials LV, and to obtain clarity on the identity of that person, all within the procedural context of the Estate of Betty Prince v Norton Hospital, Inc.

In the estate case titled Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospital, Inc. ( Jefferson Circuit 21-CI-003798 ), the Estate of Betty Prince is the client. The case involved ongoing discovery disputes, and a chain of email communications from August through September 2023 shows the efforts of counsel for the estate to obtain responses, schedule depositions, and identify an individual referenced in discovery.

On August 17, 2023, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, emailed the opposing counsel (Ryan Nafziger and Joseph Effinger) noting that while responses to the Requests for Admission had been received, there did not appear to be responses to the Interrogatories or the Document Requests. He said a letter had been sent a few weeks prior and asked for guidance on when the remaining discovery responses would be provided.

Several days later, on August 22, 2023, Koon sent two emails. In the first, at 2:32 p.m., he stated that he had not heard back regarding his previous email and that it had been an inordinate amount of time since the requests were propounded; he warned that if responses were not received very soon, he would be forced to file a Motion to Compel. He also asked whether the individual referenced in the attached document could be identified. Later that same day, at 2:46 p.m., Nafziger replied that he was in the process of completing the discovery and would have the materials to Koon by the end of the following week; Nafziger also recalled prior experience of nearly a year and a half of emailing to obtain complete responses and thanked Koon for his patience. The exchange included reference to a file or link titled BettyPrinceSFZ954585.

Also on August 22, 2023, there was a second message from Koon to Nafziger and Effinger (with BettyPrinceSFZ954585 in copy) indicating that he would continue to work toward obtaining the discovery responses, while acknowledging the ongoing effort required.

On August 28, 2023, Koon emailed again, indicating that the opposing side could have additional time to provide the discovery responses if needed. He also asked to proceed with scheduling the deposition of the individual identified in the attached document. He noted that the person’s name was not known, only initials “LV,” and he requested identification of that individual along with potential deposition dates.

On September 15, 2023, Koon followed up by asking when the discovery responses could be expected and whether the individual referenced earlier could be identified.

Finally, on September 22, 2023, Koon wrote that he had not heard back regarding the outstanding discovery responses and that he needed the client’s answers by Wednesday, September 27, 2023. He warned that if the responses were not provided by that date, he would be forced to file the attached motion. The message reiterated the same contact information and included the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer common to The Whaley Law Firm emails, which states that the message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain privileged information; if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm, avoid waiving any privilege, and not use the information or forward it to anyone not intended to receive it.

Across the sequence, the emails repeatedly documented the pursuit of discovery responses to Interrogatories and Document Requests, the status of Responses to Requests for Admission (which had been received), the attempt to identify the individual referenced by initials (LV), and the scheduling of a deposition, all while noting the need to preserve privilege and confidentiality through standard email notices. The communications reflect a persistent effort by the Estate of Betty Prince’s counsel to move the discovery process forward and to enforce timely responses under the court’s expectations.

From: Bryce Koon [bryce@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:bryce@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: [rnafziger@ppoalaw.com](mailto:rnafziger@ppoalaw.com), [jeffinger@ppoalaw.com](mailto:jeffinger@ppoalaw.com)
Cc: [sarena@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:sarena@whaleylawfirm.com) Sarena Tuttle
Date: Mon, 16 Oct 2023 14:45:48 -0400

Good afternoon counsel, 

 

As you know, on October 2nd Judge Haner signed an Order compelling your client?s discovery responses within 14 days of entry. However, we have not received any responses to date. In order to resolve this discovery issue without further court involvement, please contact me upon receipt of this correspondence and advise. 

 

If I do not receive the courtesy of a response within a reasonable time, I will be forced to file further litigation in this regard, though I doubt this will be necessary. And, as always, feel free to contact me using any of the methods below should you wish to discuss further. 

 

 

Thank you and I look forward to your responses. ?

 

W. Bryce Koon, Esq.The Whaley Law Firm 712 Lyndon Lane

Louisville, KY 40222Phone: (502) 365-5043Fax: (502) 237-3207

From: Blake GerstnerSent: Monday, October 16, 2023 3:01 PMTo: bryce@whaleylawfirm.comCc: Ryan Nafziger; Joseph Effinger; Andrea HigginsSubject: Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals (21-CI-003798)

 

Mr. Koon, 

 

We are in receipt of your message regarding the outstanding discovery responses. We have been diligently working on them and will have the responses to you by the end of today. However, some of the documents we intend to produce are confidential, and we would prefer if you would execute the attached Agreed Protective Order to protect our client?s interests to said information (I am also happy to e-sign for you ?with permission?). If you are unable to agree to our proposed order, we will produce the documents to you with your agreement to keep the documents confidential as we litigate the Protective Order. 

 

Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns. 

 

Sincerely, 

 

Blake Gerstner

Associate Attorney

 

 

716 West Main Street, Suite 300 | Louisville, Kentucky 40202 | P 502.583.9900 | F 502.587.1927 | w ppoalaw.com

It should not be copied or forwarded to any unauthorized persons. If you are not the intended recipient, please contact the sender by reply e-mail (or call 502.583.9900) to advise us of the error, and destroy all copies of the original message.

Case: Estate of Betty Prince, Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020. The client is the Estate of Betty Prince, in the matter Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals, docket number 21-CI-003798.

On October 16, 2023, at 3:01 PM, Blake Gerstner of Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC, wrote to W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, regarding the Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals. In his email, he stated that they were in receipt of Koon’s message concerning the outstanding discovery responses, and that they had been diligently working on them and would have the responses by the end of the day. He noted that some of the documents to be produced are confidential and that they would prefer Koon execute the attached Agreed Protective Order to protect their client’s interests in the information, adding that he was also happy to e-sign for Koon “with permission.” He warned that if Koon could not agree to the proposed order, they would produce the documents with Koon’s agreement to keep them confidential as the Protective Order litigation proceeded. He concluded by inviting any questions or concerns. The email carried the signature of Blake Gerstner, Associate Attorney, and included the firm’s contact information: Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC, 716 West Main Street, Suite 300, Louisville, Kentucky 40202; telephone 502.583.9900; fax 502.587.1927; website w ppoalaw.com. A confidentiality disclaimer followed, noting that the message from the law firm is for the sole use of the intended recipient and may contain confidential and privileged information; it advised against copying or forwarding to unauthorized persons, and instructed the recipient to contact the sender to report an error and to destroy all copies if not the intended recipient.

Earlier that same day, at 3:08 PM, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., appended a response from The Whaley Law Firm to Blake Gerstner. In that message, Koon thanked Gerstner for getting back to him and indicated, “You may sign on our behalf.” The email included Koon’s firm contact details: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone (502) 365-5043; fax (502) 237-3207. It also contained a standard confidentiality notice stating that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney-client privileged or otherwise protected information; if the message or any attachment were received in error, the recipient was instructed to contact The Whaley Law Firm, advise of the error, and note that no waiver of privilege shall be applicable, and that the recipient should not use or forward the information to any third party not intended to receive it. The message also reiterated the sender’s role and provided the signature block for W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020. Client: Estate of Betty Prince.

In the Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals (21-CI-003798), the deposition timeline was communicated through a sequence of emails among counsel. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent the first message on December 7, 2023, to Ryan Nafziger and several colleagues (Blake Gerstner, Joseph Effinger, Andrea Higgins), with Sarena Tuttle copied. Koon stated that they would like to take the deposition of Norton employee Lucretia Vinsom, who was identified in the Safety and Security Report provided in the discovery production. He asked whether Ms. Vinsom remains a Norton employee and requested potential deposition dates for this matter. Bryce’s message also included his firm’s contact information: W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, phone 502-365-5043, fax 502-237-3207. His email disclaimer noted that the message was intended only for the named recipient, could contain privileged information, and instructed any recipient who had received it in error to contact The Whaley Law Firm and not to disclose or forward the information.

On December 11, 2023, at about 4:48 p.m., Ryan Nafziger replied to Bryce, stating that his understanding was that Ms. Vinsom remains a Norton employee and that he was checking with her to obtain deposition dates. He also indicated an interest in requesting Mr. Robert Prince’s deposition if Bryce could check with him for dates.

Earlier that same week, on December 7, 2023, Bryce’s email was sent to Ryan Nafziger and others, including Blake Gerstner, Joseph Effinger, and Andrea Higgins, with Sarena Tuttle copied. The subject line was: Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals (21-CI-003798). Bryce reiterated the request to depose Norton employee Lucretia Vinsom and asked for potential dates. The message concluded with the same confidentiality notice as noted above.

Finally, on December 12, 2023, at 10:08:41 a.m. -0500, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, replied to Ryan Nafziger. She opened with, “Good morning, Thank you Mr. Nafziger,” and informed him that Mr. Prince is retired and has open availability. She stated that they had confirmed he currently does not have any standing appointment to work around and requested that he send dates his office would like to depose Mr. Prince. Her contact details included the firm’s address and her new email address: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com. Her signature block listed The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct line D: (502) 357-9971, office line O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and email as noted, along with the instruction to note the new email address.

Across the exchange, the case remains Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals, docket 21-CI-003798. The communications also identified the potential deposition targets: Norton employee Lucretia Vinsom (as referenced in the Safety and Security Report in the discovery materials) and Mr. Robert Prince, with the latter having the prospect of deposition dates to be provided. Bryce Koon’s December 7 email also contained a standard confidentiality disclaimer reiterating that the message was intended only for the named recipient and advising on handling if it was received in error.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020. Client: Estate of Betty Prince. Re: Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals (21-CI-003798).

In December 2023, counsel from The Whaley Law Firm coordinated deposition dates in the case Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals (21-CI-003798). The exchanges center on whether Norton employee Lucretia Vinsom may be deposed and on scheduling a deposition for Mr. Robert Prince, the latter being referenced as Mr. Prince in the emails. The correspondence involves W. Bryce Koon, Esq., the Whaley Law Firm, and colleagues including Sarena M. Tuttle, Ryan Nafziger, Blake Gerstner, Joseph Effinger, Andrea Higgins, and Aaron Whaley. The note set captures four email communications, spanning December 7, 11, 12, and 26, 2023, with standard confidentiality and privilege notices included in each message.

On December 7, 2023, at 3:50 PM, Bryce Koon sent the initial request. He asked counsel to confirm whether Norton employee Lucretia Vinsom, identified in the Safety and Security Report provided in the opposing party’s discovery production, is still employed by Norton and, if so, to provide potential deposition dates. His message concluded with his contact information: W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, phone (502) 365-5043, fax (502) 237-3207. The email included the customary attorney-client privileged disclaimer indicating the message is intended only for the named recipient and outlining the precautionary steps if received in error.

Three days later, on December 11, 2023, at 4:48 PM, Ryan Nafziger replied. He indicated his understanding that Ms. Vinsom remained a Norton employee and that he was checking with her to obtain deposition dates. He also stated an additional desire to request Mr. Robert Prince’s deposition if Bryce Koon could check with him for dates. This message was addressed to Bryce Koon, with copies to Blake Gerstner and Joseph Effinger, Andrea Higgins, and Sarena Tuttle, and it carried the same standard confidentiality disclaimer.

On December 12, 2023, at 10:08 AM, Sarena Tuttle responded to Nafziger. She informed him that Mr. Prince is retired and has open availability, and she noted that they had confirmed Mr. Prince currently does not have any standing appointment to work around. She requested that Nafziger’s office provide dates for deposing Mr. Prince. This reply was sent to Ryan Nafziger with copies to Bryce Koon, Blake Gerstner, Joseph Effinger, Andrea Higgins, and Aaron Whaley, and she also included a note that Mr. Prince’s information reflects a new email address for the sender. The message ended with the Whaley Law Firm’s standard disclaimer about confidentiality and privilege.

Finally, on December 26, 2023, at 3:15 PM (−0500), Bryce Koon followed up with the group. He asked, “Do we have any potential dates yet for Ms. Vinsom’s deposition?” The email was sent to the same recipients listed in the first message, with the Whaley Law Firm’s confidentially disclaimer included.

Across these communications, the core issues being pursued were (1) whether Norton employee Lucretia Vinsom is currently employed and available for deposition, with counsel seeking potential deposition dates, and (2) whether Mr. Robert Prince—described as retired and with open availability—could be deposed, with the opposing side asked to propose dates. The exchanges also record the evolving understanding of Mr. Prince’s status (retired with no standing work commitments) and the ongoing effort to coordinate deposition scheduling, all within the case captioned Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals (21-CI-003798). The messages consistently include the standard attorney-client privilege/confidentiality notices.

Case: Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020. Client: Estate of Betty Prince. This note records a series of internal emails regarding the Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals (case number 21-CI-003798), focusing on scheduling depositions of two individuals identified in discovery: Norton employee Lucretia Vinsom and Mr. Robert Prince.

The exchange began on December 7, 2023, when W. Bryce Koon, an attorney with The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to Ryan Nafziger and others asking for potential deposition dates for Norton employee Lucretia Vinsom, who was identified in the Safety and Security Report provided in the discovery production. Bryce also asked whether Ms. Vinsom remained a Norton employee and requested potential dates for her deposition.

On December 11, 2023, Ryan Nafziger replied to Bryce (and copied others) that his understanding was that Ms. Vinsom was still a Norton employee. He said he would check with her to obtain deposition dates and added that he would also like to request Mr. Robert Prince’s deposition if Bryce could check with him for dates.

On December 12, 2023, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, responded. She stated that Mr. Prince is retired and has open availability, and that he currently does not have any standing appointment to work around. She asked that dates be sent for deposing Mr. Prince.

On December 26, 2023, Bryce Koon followed up via email to Sarena Tuttle and Ryan Nafziger, asking whether there were any potential dates yet for Ms. Vinsom’s deposition.

On December 29, 2023, Ryan Nafziger replied that he was still working on obtaining dates and would get back to Bryce the following week, wishing everyone a Happy New Year. This exchange was part of a forwarded thread that Bryce later circulated, which included Bryce’s earlier inquiry about Ms. Vinsom’s deposition dates and Ryan’s ongoing efforts to secure dates.

The emails include standard attorney-client privilege disclosures and signatures. Bryce’s messages show the Whaley Law Firm contact details (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207) and note that the email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com is a new contact. The messages also list other recipients who were copied, including Blake Gerstner, Joseph Effinger, Andrea Higgins, and Aaron Whaley, among others. The overarching topic is coordinating deposition dates for Lucretia Vinsom, a Norton employee identified in discovery, and for Mr. Robert Prince, a party associated with the estate who was described as retired and available for deposition.

Case: Estate of Betty Prince. The Estate of Betty Prince is the client in the matter styled Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals, case number 21-CI-003798. This note summarizes a sequence of email communications among counsel at The Whaley Law Firm and PPOA Law, concerning deposition dates for witnesses identified in discovery, and specifically regarding Norton Hospitals employee Lucretia Vinsom and Mr. Robert Prince.

On December 7, 2023, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Ryan Nafziger and colleagues, with Sarena Tuttle copied, requesting the deposition of Norton employee Lucretia Vinsom. The deposition was to be taken based on information identified in the Safety and Security Report that appeared in the discovery production. Mr. Koon asked whether Ms. Vinsom remained employed by Norton and requested potential deposition dates for her. The subject line reflected the matter: Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals (21-CI-003798). The message included The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details and a standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer. A signature image reference was present in the email.

A reply followed on December 11, 2023, from Ryan Nafziger. He stated that his understanding was that Ms. Vinsom was still a Norton employee and that he was checking with her to obtain deposition dates. He also indicated an interest in arranging the deposition of Mr. Robert Prince, asking the recipients to check with him for dates as well. This message also carried a standard privilege disclaimer.

On December 12, 2023, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm (address: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line 502-357-9971; office line 502-583-4022 ext. 104; email: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; note: new email address), responded to Ryan Nafziger. She thanked him and confirmed that Mr. Prince is retired and has open availability. She noted that Mr. Prince does not have any standing appointment to work around, and she asked that dates be sent for depositing Mr. Prince.

On December 26, 2023, Bryce Koon sent another email regarding the case. Addressed to Sarena Tuttle and Ryan Nafziger with the same recipients in CC, he asked whether there were any potential dates yet for Ms. Vinsom’s deposition. The message again referenced the Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals (21-CI-003798) and included the standard privilege disclaimer and attachments customary to such communications.

Finally, on December 29, 2023, Ryan Nafziger replied to Bryce and Sarena, noting that he was still working on obtaining deposition dates and would get back to them the following week. He concluded with New Year wishes. This message also carried the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer.

Throughout the correspondence, the parties consistently referenced deposing Norton employee Lucretia Vinsom as identified in the Safety and Security Report from discovery, and Mr. Robert Prince (the estate’s related party) as a potential deponent. They discussed whether Ms. Vinsom remained a Norton employee and the availability of Mr. Prince, who is retired, with no current standing appointment, and thus potentially available for a deposition. The exchanges also included formal signatures and standard privilege notices typical of this type of litigation communication.

Case: Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020. Client: Estate of Betty Prince. This note concerns the Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals (case number 21-CI-003798). The correspondence below reflects efforts by counsel for the Estate to schedule depositions in the Norton Hospitals matter, specifically deposition dates for Norton employee Lucretia Vinsom, as identified in Norton’s discovery materials, and a potential deposition of Mr. Robert Prince.

On December 7, 2023, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to counsel at PPOA and to Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, requesting potential deposition dates for Norton employee Lucretia Vinsom, who is identified in the Safety and Security Report included in the discovery production. He asked to confirm whether Ms. Vinsom remains a Norton employee and to provide dates for her deposition.

On December 11, 2023, Ryan Nafziger replied that Ms. Vinsom is still a Norton employee and that he was checking with her to obtain deposition dates. He also stated an interest in requesting Mr. Robert Prince’s deposition if dates could be arranged.

On December 12, 2023, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, replied. She stated that Mr. Prince is retired and has open availability, with no standing appointment to contend with. She asked that the offices send dates for deposing Mr. Prince.

On December 7, 2023, in a separate thread, Bryce Koon had also asked whether Norton employee Lucretia Vinsom could be deposed and requested potential dates for that deposition, referencing Vinsom’s identification in the Safety and Security Report.

On December 26, 2023, Bryce Koon again asked whether there were any potential dates for Ms. Vinsom’s deposition.

On December 29, 2023, Ryan Nafziger responded that he was still working on obtaining dates and would get back next week, and he extended holiday wishes for a Happy New Year.

On January 8, 2024, Bryce Koon sent a follow-up to Ryan Nafziger asking whether there had been progress on obtaining dates for Ms. Vinsom’s deposition.

All of these messages include customary attorney-client privilege and confidentiality notices: the electronic messages are intended only for the named recipients; they may contain privileged or protected information; if received in error, the recipient is instructed to contact The Whaley Law Firm and not to use or forward the information, as no waiver of privilege applies.

Additional context from the thread includes contact details and identifiers for the parties. The Whaley Law Firm is located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with Bryce Koon’s phone number listed as (502) 365-5043 and a fax number of (502) 364-9363 (some messages reflect a fax number of (502) 237-3207). Sarena Tuttle’s contact information is listed as D: (502) 357-9971 and O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and her email is Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noted as the new email address). The correspondence to and from Ryan Nafziger and other recipients includes the PPOA firm addresses and the other participants: Blake Gerstner, Joseph Effinger, Andrea Higgins, and Aaron Whaley.

In short, between early December 2023 and early January 2024, counsel pursued scheduling for Lucretia Vinsom’s deposition (and discussed Mr. Prince’s deposition as well). It was established that Ms. Vinsom remains a Norton employee and that Mr. Prince is retired with open availability and no scheduling conflicts due to standing appointments. No deposition dates were provided in these messages, and the parties continued to seek available dates for both depositions.

episodes.natural_language:
In the Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals, docket number 21-CI-003798, the Estate of Betty Prince (the client) and The Whaley Law Firm were coordinating depositions related to the case. The communications, occurring between December 2023 and February 2024, sought to schedule depositions of two witnesses: Norton employee Lucretia Vinsom and Mr. Robert Prince (the decedent’s father). The principal participants were W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, and counsel for Norton Hospitals, including Ryan Nafziger and litigation paralegal Sarena M. Tuttle. (Sarena’s signature notes a new email address, and the signature block for Bryce includes the Whaley firm’s Louisville address and contact numbers.)

The scheduling effort began on December 7, 2023, when Bryce Koon asked whether Norton employee Lucretia Vinsom could be deposed, noting that Vinsom was identified in the Safety and Security Report provided in Norton’s discovery production, and requesting potential deposition dates if she remained with Norton. In reply on December 11, 2023, Ryan Nafziger indicated his understanding that Ms. Vinsom was still a Norton employee and that he was checking with her to obtain deposition dates; he also expressed a desire to request Mr. Robert Prince’s deposition if dates could be found. On December 12, 2023, Sarena Tuttle, Norton’s litigation paralegal, replied that Mr. Prince was retired and had open availability, with no standing appointment to work around, and she asked that dates be provided for deposing Mr. Prince.

Bryce followed up on December 26, 2023, asking for potential dates for Lucretia Vinsom’s deposition. On December 29, 2023, Nafziger replied that he was still working on obtaining dates and would get back next week, and he wished everyone a happy new year. The same day, Bryce had earlier communications with the group regarding the search for dates, including availability inquiries for Ms. Vinsom.

In early January 2024, Nafziger provided an update on Ms. Vinsom’s availability: she was available January 29 and 30, and February 1, 2, and 5–9; she would be unavailable the week of February 12–16, but could be scheduled after that if needed. Nafziger noted that he could host the depositions at his office and that they could potentially be scheduled on the same day for both witnesses. Bryce responded on January 8, 2024, asking whether progress had been made on obtaining dates for Ms. Vinsom’s deposition. A follow-up exchange occurred on January 9, 2024, when Bryce wrote that he had spoken with Mr. Prince and that Tuesday, February 6 would work best for all parties. He closed with his customary contact information.

Thus, the record reflects a coordinated effort across December 2023 and early January 2024 to schedule depositions of Lucretia Vinsom and Mr. Robert Prince, with the parties ultimately aiming to conduct both depositions on a single day (Tuesday, February 6, 2024) at the office of the plaintiffs’ counsel, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, in Louisville, Kentucky.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals (21-CI-003798). Client: Estate of Betty Prince.

In the binders for the Estate of Betty Prince, counsel began a series of email exchanges in December 2023 and January 2024 concerning depositions of two Norton witnesses in the matter. The first request, dated December 7, 2023, came from W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm. He asked whether Norton employee Lucretia Vinsom, identified in the Safety and Security Report produced in discovery, would be available for deposition and requested potential dates for scheduling her deposition.

On December 11, 2023, Ryan Nafziger replied that Ms. Vinsom is apparently still a Norton employee and that he would check with her to obtain deposition dates. He also indicated a desire to request the deposition of Mr. Robert Prince, asking Bryce Koon to check with Mr. Prince for possible dates.

The following day, December 12, 2023, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, responded. She stated that Mr. Prince is retired and has open availability, and that he currently does not have any standing appointments to work around. She advised sending dates for Mr. Prince’s deposition.

Later in December, on December 26, 2023, Bryce Koon asked whether there were any potential dates yet for Ms. Vinsom’s deposition. Ryan Nafziger did not provide dates at that time but indicated on December 29, 2023, that he was still working on obtaining dates and would follow up the next week, wishing everyone a Happy New Year.

As January 2024 began, Ryan provided a concrete window for Ms. Vinsom’s deposition. On January 8, 2024, he informed Bryce that Ms. Vinsom was available January 29, 30 and February 1, 2 and 5–9. He noted that she would be unavailable the week of February 12–16, but could be available afterward if those dates did not work. He offered to host the depositions at his office and suggested that both depositions could be completed on the same day.

Bryce followed up the same day, January 8, 2024, asking whether any progress had been made on scheduling Ms. Vinsom’s deposition.

In subsequent exchanges on January 9, 2024, the parties refined the plan. Ryan noted that February 6 would be the date and asked for a preferred time, proposing the first deposition at 10:00 and the second at noon or thereafter. Bryce confirmed that Tuesday, February 6 would work best for all involved. He included the Whaley Law Firm’s contact details and a standard attorney-client privilege notice commonly attached to emails. The Whaley Law Firm’s address listed was 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with a phone number of (502) 365-5043 and a fax number of (502) 364-9363. The communications also carried the customary disclaimer about privileged information and the instruction to contact the firm if the message was received in error.

Earlier in the thread, Bryce’s December 7, 2023 request to depose Lucretia Vinsom had sought dates for her deposition, and Ryan’s December 11, 2023 reply confirmed his belief that she remained a Norton employee and that he would check with her about deposition dates, while also noting an interest in deposing Mr. Prince if possible. By December 12, 2023, Sarena Tuttle had clarified that Mr. Prince was retired but available, and instructed the team to propose dates for his deposition. The communications reflect Ryan Nafziger’s role in coordinating depositions and hosting arrangements, while Bryce Koon and Sarena Tuttle interacted with respect to who would be deposed and when.

Across these communications, the objective remained clear: schedule two depositions—one for Lucretia Vinsom and one for Mr. Robert Prince—on a single day to be determined, with February 6, 2024 as the proposed date, and to commence with the first deposition at 10:00 and the second at 12:00 or thereafter, with the depositions to be hosted at Ryan Nafziger’s office if feasible. The notes also reflect the evolving availability: Ms. Vinsom’s availability windows (January 29, 30; February 1, 2; and February 5–9) and her unavailability the week of February 12–16, and Mr. Prince’s status as retired with open schedules.

For completeness, the communications include standard attorney-client privilege notices and new email address references for Sarena Tuttle, who signs as Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals, 21-CI-003798. The client is the Estate of Betty Prince. The correspondence centers on scheduling depositions of two potential witnesses: Norton employee Lucretia Vinsom and Mr. Robert Prince (the latter described as retired with open availability). The exchanges spanned December 2023 through January 2024 and involved counsel from The Whaley Law Firm (Bryce W. Koon, Esq.; Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager) and counsel from PPOA Law (Ryan Nafziger, Esq.; Joseph Effinger, Esq.; Andrea Higgins, Esq.), with the Whaley firm’s contact details and the PPOA firm’s contact details listed in the signatures. The messages also included standard attorney-client privilege disclosures in every electronic transmission, and Sarena Tuttle noted a new email address in her signature.

The discussion began on December 7, 2023, when Bryce Koon asked whether Norton employee Lucretia Vinsom remained with Norton and requested potential deposition dates. On December 11, 2023, Ryan Nafziger replied that Ms. Vinsom was still a Norton employee and that he would check with her to obtain deposition dates; he also indicated an interest in deposing Mr. Robert Prince if dates could be found. The following day, December 12, 2023, Sarena Tuttle responded that Mr. Prince is retired and has open availability, with no standing appointment to work around, and requested dates for deposing Mr. Prince.

Further scheduling back-and-forth continued through December 2023. On December 26, 2023, Bryce again asked for potential dates for Ms. Vinsom’s deposition, and on December 29, 2023, Ryan noted he was still working on obtaining dates and would respond the following week, wishing everyone a Happy New Year. By December 12, 2023, Sarena had already indicated that Mr. Prince’s deposition could be scheduled given his retirement and available windows.

In early January 2024, the parties narrowed the window for Ms. Vinsom’s deposition. On January 8, 2024, Ryan stated that Ms. Vinsom was available January 29, 30 and February 1, 2 and February 5–9, with a week of February 12–16 unavailable but the witness could be available afterward; he suggested arranging both depositions on the same day and hosting at his office. Bryce Koon replied later that day, asking for progress on securing dates for Ms. Vinsom’s deposition. Ryan reaffirmed Ms. Vinsom’s availability and again offered to host at his office, asking whether any of the listed dates would work for the client and whether both depositions could be done on the same day.

On January 9, 2024, Bryce indicated that Tuesday, February 6 would work best for all involved. Ryan then sought preference on the time for the day, proposing the first deposition at 10:00 a.m. and the second at noon or thereafter. The following day, January 10, 2024, Sarena replied that starting the day at 10:00 a.m. was perfect for their office and provided her contact information, including a new email address (Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com) and the firm’s full contact details. The message also carried the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer.

In summary, the parties settled on scheduling two depositions for Tuesday, February 6, 2024, with the planned sequence to begin at 10:00 a.m. for the first deposition and the second at 12:00 p.m. or later, to be conducted on the same day at Ryan Nafziger’s office, pending confirmations of Ms. Vinsom’s and Mr. Prince’s availabilities. The correspondence repeatedly confirms Ms. Vinsom’s status as a Norton employee and Mr. Prince’s retirement with open availability, and all communications include the customary privilege notices and firm signatures.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020
Client: Estate of Betty Prince

In the Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospital, communications among counsel during January and February 2024 concerned depositions in the case. The Whaley Law Firm represents the Estate of Betty Prince, and Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC represents Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett in related matters.

On January 10, 2024, at 3:54 PM, Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to Andrea Higgins with copies to bryce@whaleylawfirm.com, Ryan Nafziger, and Joseph Effinger. She stated, “Thank you. Here is the NTTD for Nurse Vinsom as well,” indicating that a Notice To Take Deposition (NTTD) for Nurse Vinsom had been prepared. Tuttle’s contact information was included: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line 502-357-9971; office line 502-583-4022 ext. 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, noting a new email address.

Earlier that same day, at approximately 3:00 PM, Andrea L. Higgins, Legal Assistant to Joseph M. Effinger, Esq.; Matthew A. Piekarski, Esq.; Ryan D. Nafziger, Esq.; and Blake Gerstner, Esq., at the law firm Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC, replied. She attached the notice to take the deposition of Robert Prince on February 6 at 12 noon, to be held at PPOA. Her email address was ahiggins@ppoalaw.com, and her firm’s contact details were listed as 716 West Main Street, Suite 300, Louisville, KY 40202; phone 502-583-9900; fax 502-587-1927; website w ppoalaw.com. The message from Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett carried a standard confidentiality disclaimer stating that the email was for the sole use of the intended recipient(s) and may contain confidential and privileged information; it should not be copied or forwarded to unauthorized persons, and if the recipient was not the intended recipient, they should contact the sender and destroy all copies.

On February 5, 2024, there was an exchange regarding the upcoming depositions. An electronic message titled “FW: Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospital” was sent by W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, from the address bryce@whaleylawfirm.com and addressed to the file recipient bettyprincesfz954585@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com. The forward was dated Monday, February 5, 2024, at 11:18:31 AM (Eastern Time). The Whaley Law Firm contact details appeared in the signature block: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-364-9363. The forwarded note carried the customary attorney-client privilege disclaimer, stating that the message is intended only for the named recipient and that any inadvertent receipt should be reported to The Whaley Law Firm, with no waiver of privilege, and that the information should not be used or forwarded to others.

Within the same chain, Bryce Koon had sent an initial message on February 5, 2024 at 11:05 AM to Ryan Nafziger and Joseph Effinger, with Sarena Tuttle and Andrea Higgins in cc, asking, “Good morning all, Just wanted to confirm that we are still set for tomorrow’s depositions.” The response from Ryan Nafziger came a few minutes later, at 11:09 AM, saying simply, “Good morning – confirmed on our end.” The reply from Nafziger was also conveyed within the same email chain.

In sum, the record reflects that, in January 2024, counsel coordinated deposition notices and NTTDs for witnesses including Nurse Vinsom and Robert Prince, with Robert Prince’s deposition specifically scheduled for February 6 at 12 noon at PPOA. By February 5, 2024, counsel confirmed that the depositions were still set for the following day. The communications include standard privilege notices and confidentiality disclaimers unique to each firm, and they reference the involved parties and the scheduling of depositions in the Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospital.
