On February 5, 2024, Sarena Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers' Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line 502-357-9971; office line 502-583-4022 ext. 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; please note the new email address) sent an email to the Scheduling Department at Kentuckiana Reporters (schedule@kentuckianareporters.com). The email was also CC’d to AGWhaley@WhaleyLawFirm.com, Bryce Koon, and Ryan Nafziger. The message stated: “Good morning, Tomorrow's deposition has been confirmed. Thank you.”

Earlier that day, on February 5, 2024, around 11:15 a.m., the Scheduling Department had sent a message attaching the confirmation for tomorrow's proceeding and asked the recipient to review and confirm whether it would proceed as scheduled or to provide any necessary revisions. They requested an estimated duration if available. The confirmation indicated that the proceeding would include a Court Reporter (checked) and no other services (Videographer, Interpreter, Conference Room, ZOOM Connection, and Telephone Conference were not selected).

The scheduled deposition details are as follows: Date 2/6/2024, Time 10:00 AM. Client listed is Aaron Whaley, Esquire, of The Whaley Law Firm. The Case Style is Robert Prince (Betty Prince) vs. Norton Hospital, Inc. The Judge/Witness noted is Lucretia Vinsom. The location is Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett in Louisville, at 716 West Main Street, Suite 300, Louisville, Kentucky, 502-583-9900. The communication closes with “Thank you for scheduling with us!”

The email correspondence also contains a standard confidentiality notice stating that the information is intended solely for the recipient, may contain privileged information, and may be subject to Federal Rules of Evidence 408 or other laws; recipients should not file copies of the email in publicly accessible records; if the reader is not the intended recipient or the person responsible for delivering it to the intended recipient, dissemination or copying of the communication is strictly prohibited.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020. Client: Estate of Betty Prince. This file concerns the Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals, docket number 21-CI-003798, in which the plaintiff is the Estate of Betty Prince.

Between October 16 and October 25, 2023, a series of email communications took place between counsel representing the Estate and counsel for Norton Hospitals regarding discovery and a protective order, with documents and records to be produced under that order. On Monday, October 16, 2023, at 3:01 p.m., Blake Gerstner of Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC wrote to Bryce Koons of The Whaley Law Firm. He apologized for the delay and stated that attached please be found the defendant’s discovery responses. He said they would forward a OneDrive link the next day containing the referenced medical records and bills, as well as a signed verification page, and that once the Agreed Protective Order had been entered they would forward the applicable documents. He concluded by inviting any questions or concerns, and his email included the customary confidentiality notice.

Later the same afternoon, at 3:08 p.m., Bryce Koon responded: “Thank you for getting back to me. You may sign on our behalf.” He signed off with his contact information for The Whaley Law Firm, including his Louisville address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, phone and fax numbers, and his electronic signature block. The message also contained the firm’s standard confidentiality disclaimer.

Earlier that day, at 3:01 p.m., Blake had also noted in a separate message that they were in receipt of the outstanding discovery responses, had been diligently working on them, and would have the responses by the end of the day. He reiterated that some documents were confidential and reiterated the preference that Bryce execute the attached Agreed Protective Order to protect their client’s interests; he added that if Bryce could not agree to the proposed order, they would still produce the documents with an agreement to keep them confidential while the Protective Order was litigated. This message also carried the firm’s confidentiality notice.

At 5:06 p.m. on October 16, 2023, Blake sent another message reiterating that they had received the request for discovery responses and that they would have them by the end of the day. He explained that some of the documents were confidential and that they would prefer Bryce to execute the attached Agreed Protective Order; he also offered to e-sign for Bryce with permission. He confirmed that they had been diligently working on the responses and that once the Agreed Protective Order had been entered, they would forward the applicable documents. The email again included Blake’s signature block and the firm’s confidentiality notice.

More than a week later, on Monday, October 16, 2023, at 3:01 p.m., Blake sent another message in the thread indicating that the parties were awaiting the protective order’s entry and that the documents to be produced were confidential, with a proposed protective order to govern access. The tone throughout this sequence was to secure a protective order before sharing the confidential materials.

On Wednesday, October 25, 2023, at 10:01 a.m., Blake Gerstner again wrote to Bryce Koons regarding the same Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals matter. He apologized for the delay and attached the documents referenced in his previous email, produced pursuant to the agreed protective order, along with a one-drive link containing the Plaintiff’s medical and billing records. He asked Bryce to review and to contact him if there were questions or concerns. The body of this email included the standard signature for Blake Gerstner, Associate Attorney, Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC, with the firm’s Louisville address (716 West Main Street, Suite 300, Louisville, KY 40202), telephone and fax numbers, and the website w ppoalaw.com. It also included the firm’s confidentiality notice.

The emails also show the broader context of the correspondence, including the presence of standard confidentiality language in each message and the logistical details of production under the protective order. The subject line on these communications consistently read: “Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals (21-CI-003798).” The October 25 exchange was forwarded within the team: Bryce Koon forwarded Blake’s October 25 message as “FW: Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals (21-CI-003798)” to Sarena Tuttle at sarena@whaleylawfirm.com, with a cc to bettyprincesfz954585@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, dated October 25, 2023, 10:37:03 -0400.

Attachments and materials referenced across the chain included documents produced under the Agreed Protective Order, along with a one-drive link containing the Plaintiff’s medical and billing records, and, in one message, a signed verification page. The communications also recorded the ongoing use of a protective order to govern the sharing and handling of confidential information, with the expectation that the protective order would be entered before full production of the documents.

In summary, the record reflects a coordinated discovery process in the Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals, centered on compliance with an Agreed Protective Order, the production of defendant discovery responses, and the provision of medical and billing records via a one-drive link to the plaintiff’s counsel, all within a sequence of dated emails from October 16 through October 25, 2023, including professional signatures and confidentiality notices typical of this practice.

In the Estate of Betty Prince, the case titled Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals Inc. is filed in Jefferson Circuit Court under docket number 21-CI-003798. The file note, labeled Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020, concerns the Estate of Betty Prince as the client.

On Monday, April 22, 2024 at 10:43:22 a.m. Eastern Time, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm in Louisville, Kentucky, sent an email to rnafziger@ppoalaw.com and jeffinger@ppoalaw.com with a cc to bettyprincesfz954585@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com. The subject line read: RE: Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals Inc. (Jefferson Circuit 21-CI-003798). In the body he wrote good afternoon counsel and noted that he was following up on the below requests, asking counsel to advise when responses could be expected. He closed with his standard signature block, which included The Whaley Law Firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222 and the telephone and fax numbers (Phone: 502-365-5043; Fax: 502-364-9363). The message carried a privilege disclaimer stating that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney-client privileged or protected information; if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm, there is no waiver of privilege, and the information should not be used or forwarded to any third party not intended to receive it.

This April 22 communication followed earlier correspondence from Bryce Koon in March 2024. On Tuesday, March 19, 2024 at 12:35 p.m., Koon sent another email to rnafziger@ppoalaw.com and jeffinger@ppoalaw.com with the same case reference in the subject line. The body began, Good afternoon counsel, and stated, “Attached please find Plaintiff’s Supplemental Discovery Requests. If you need anything else from me in this regard, please let me know.” This message also carried the same Whaley Law Firm signature and contact information, along with the identical attorney-client privilege disclaimer.

Approximately one minute later, at 12:36 p.m. on March 19, 2024, Koon sent a follow-up email to the same recipients, again with the subject Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals Inc. (Jefferson Circuit 21-CI-003798). In this message, he wrote, “Apologies – forgot to attach them!” and included the same signature block and privilege disclaimer as in the previous emails.

Across these messages, each email included The Whaley Law Firm’s standard privilege disclaimer, reiterating that the electronic communications are intended only for the named recipients, may contain attorney-client privileged or protected information, and that if the message or any attachment was received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and advise accordingly, with no waiver of privilege and instructions not to use or forward the information to any third party not intended to receive it.

episodes.natural_language:
In the case captioned Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals Inc. (Jefferson Circuit Court, 21-CI-003798), the Estate of Betty Prince is the client. The matter concerns ongoing discovery disputes between counsel for the estate and counsel for Norton Hospitals. The principal participants in the email thread include Ryan Nafziger of PPOA Law, representing the estate, and Bryce Koon, Esq. of The Whaley Law Firm, along with Joseph Effinger (also of PPOA Law). The CC list across the exchanges includes the filevine email account for bettyprincesfz954585@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com and Sarena Tuttle.

The communications unfolded as follows. On March 19, 2024, at 12:35 p.m., Bryce Koon sent an email to Ryan Nafziger and Joseph Effinger, with the subject referencing Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals Inc. (Jefferson Circuit 21-CI-003798). In that message, he stated that Plaintiff’s Supplemental Discovery Requests were attached and asked to let him know if anything else was needed. A follow-up message shortly thereafter, at 12:36 p.m., from Bryce Koon contained the line, “Apologies – forgot to attach them!” indicating an attachment issue. A separate prior message also appeared in the chain at 12:35 p.m. where Mr. Koon again advised that the Plaintiff’s Supplemental Discovery Requests were attached and invited any further input, followed by the brief 12:36 p.m. follow-up noting the attachment oversight, with the standard attorney-client confidentiality disclaimer included in each email.

On April 22, 2024, at 10:43 a.m., Bryce Koon again wrote to counsel, this time advising, “Good afternoon counsel, Just writing to follow up on the below requests. Please advise when we may expect responses in this regard.” His signature block identified him as W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, with Louisville contact details, and a standard confidentiality notice was included in the message.

There is another April 22, 2024 entry at 10:43 a.m. that repeats the confidentiality language and the attorney contact information, consistent with the firm’s email footer.

On April 30, 2024, at 11:00 a.m., Bryce Koon sent a further follow-up email: “Good afternoon counsel, I am again writing to follow up on the outstanding discovery requests. If I do not hear from you by Thursday, I will be forced to file a motion to compel in this regard.” This message also carried his signing block with the same firm information and the standard confidentiality disclaimer.

Finally, on May 2, 2024, Ryan Nafziger replied to Bryce Koon and Joseph Effinger. In his message, Nafziger apologized for the late reply and stated that he was still waiting on some responsive information, but he hoped to have these materials to counsel by the end of the next week. This May 2, 2024 email was sent from Ryan Nafziger and was copied to Bryce Koon and Joseph Effinger, with the CC’d recipients including bettyprincesfz954585@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com and Sarena Tuttle. The note’s date and time were Thu, May 2, 2024, at 13:44:02 +0000.

Across these messages, the correspondence repeatedly references Plaintiff’s Supplemental Discovery Requests and the estate’s discovery timeline, with multiple follow-ups from The Whaley Law Firm about responses and a late-count response from the estate’s counsel acknowledging the need for information and seeking to avoid a motion to compel. Each email contains the standard attorney-client confidentiality notice customary to such communications.

In the case titled Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals Inc. (Jefferson Circuit Court, 21-CI-003798), the Estate of Betty Prince is represented by The Whaley Law Firm. The note documents a sequence of discovery communications between the firm and opposing counsel, spanning March through May 2024, with the matter tracked under the file Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020.

On March 19, 2024, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to opposing counsel at PPOA Law (rnafziger@ppoalaw.com and jeffinger@ppoalaw.com), with the subject Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals Inc. (Jefferson Circuit 21-CI-003798). In that message, he attached Plaintiff’s Supplemental Discovery Requests and cc’d the Estate’s Filevine portal address bettyprincesfz954585@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com and Sarena Tuttle. Shortly after, at 12:36 PM on the same day, Koon followed up with a separate email apologizing that the attachments had not been included. The emails each carried The Whaley Law Firm’s standard confidentiality disclaimer, noting that the messages are intended only for the named recipient and that, if received in error, the recipient should contact the firm and not disclose or use privileged information.

A little over a month later, on April 22, 2024, Koon again wrote to opposing counsel (to the same recipients, rnafziger and jeffinger, with the same subject line) to follow up on the requests. In that message, he stated, “Good afternoon counsel, Just writing to follow up on the below requests. Please advise when we may expect responses in this regard,” and he again signed as W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s Louisville, Kentucky address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222) and contact information (Phone: 502-365-5043; Fax: 502-364-9363). The message reiterated the standard attorney-client confidentiality notice.

On April 30, 2024, Koon sent another follow-up regarding the outstanding discovery requests. He wrote, “Good afternoon counsel, I am again writing to follow up on the outstanding discovery requests. If I do not hear from you by Thursday, I will be forced to file a motion to compel in this regard.” This email also carried the Whaley Law Firm signature block and confidentiality notice.

The following day, May 2, 2024, Ryan Nafziger of PPOA Law replied to Bryce Koon. In his reply, Nafziger apologized for the late response, explained that he was still waiting on some responsive information, and stated that he hoped to have the information to Bryce by the end of the next week. Nafziger closed his message with a brief thank you. The thread continued with the standard email formatting and the confidentiality disclaimer included in the outgoing communications.

In summary, this note tracks a persistent discovery dispute in Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals Inc., with plaintiff’s counsel repeatedly requesting discovery responses, issuing warnings of a potential motion to compel if no timely reply, and opposing counsel replying on May 2, 2024, indicating that responsive information was still being gathered and would be provided by the end of the following week. The communications include multiple CCs to the Estate’s Filevine portal and to Sarena Tuttle, and all messages incorporate the Whaley Law Firm’s contact details and privilege notices.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020. Client: the Estate of Betty Prince. This matter is styled Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals Inc. in Jefferson Circuit Court, case number 21-CI-003798.

The communications in this note arise from the estate’s discovery efforts in the above case and show a sequence of email correspondence between The Whaley Law Firm (attorney W. Bryce Koon, Esq.) and counsel for Norton Hospitals, with several recipients and CCs, between March and June of 2024. The Whaley Law Firm’s emails consistently carried their standard professional disclaimers about privilege and confidentiality.

On March 19, 2024, at 12:35 PM, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Ryan Nafziger (to rnafziger@ppoalaw.com) and Joseph Effinger (jeffinger@ppoalaw.com), with the bettyprincesfz954585@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com address CC’d. The subject was: “Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals Inc. (Jefferson Circuit 21-CI-003798).” In the body, Koon wrote: “Attached please find Plaintiff’s Supplemental Discovery Requests. If you need anything else from me in this regard, please let me know.” The signature included The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; Phone: 502-365-5043; Fax: 502-364-9363. A follow-up message was sent at 12:36 PM the same day stating: “Apologies – forgot to attach them!” with the same signature and confidentiality disclaimer.

On April 22, 2024, at 10:43 AM, Koon sent another message to rnafziger@ppoalaw.com and jeffinger@ppoalaw.com, CC’ing bettyprincesfz954585@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, with the subject: “RE: Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals Inc. (Jefferson Circuit 21-CI-003798).” The body read: “Good afternoon counsel, Just writing to follow up on the below requests. Please advise when we may expect responses in this regard.” The message again carried The Whaley Law Firm’s standard contact details and confidentiality notice.

On April 30, 2024, at 11:00 AM, Koon emailed Ryan Nafziger and Joseph Effinger (CC’d to bettyprincesfz954585@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com) regarding the same matter, with the subject line unchanged. He wrote: “Good afternoon counsel, I am again writing to follow up on the outstanding discovery requests. If I do not hear from you by Thursday, I will be forced to file a motion to compel in this regard.” The email again included the firm’s address and contact information, along with the confidentiality disclaimer.

On May 2, 2024, at 9:44 AM, Ryan Nafziger replied to Bryce Koon (and CC’d Joseph Effinger, with Betty Prince’s file likely cc’d as well). Nafziger wrote: “Hi Bryce, Apologies for the late response. I am still waiting on some responsive information, but hope to have these to you by the end of next week.” This message also included the standard firm footer and confidentiality notice.

On June 3, 2024, at 9:35 AM, Nafziger sent another reply to Bryce Koon: “Bryce, Following our phone call last week, I just wanted to let you know that I am still hoping to provide our responses shortly – just waiting for a few more documents.” This communication appears in the thread that was later forwarded by Bryce Koon on June 3, 2024 at 10:10:43 AM, when he forwarded the email from Nafziger titled “RE: Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals Inc. (Jefferson Circuit 21-CI-003798).”

In sum, the notes document a back-and-forth about Plaintiff’s Supplemental Discovery Requests in the Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals Inc., including the initial attachment of the discovery requests on March 19, a correction that the attachments were forgotten, multiple follow-ups from The Whaley Law Firm seeking responses, and subsequent delays and expectations regarding production of responsive information. The correspondence consistently referenced the case caption and number (Jefferson Circuit 21-CI-003798), included Nahon Hospitals’ counsel’s email addresses (rnafziger@ppoalaw.com and jeffinger@ppoalaw.com), and CC’d the representative file address bettyprincesfz954585@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, with Joseph Effinger CC’d on several messages. The Whaley Law Firm’s communications also repeatedly contained their standard confidentiality and privilege notices.

episodes.original_body:
Case: Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020
Client: Estate of Betty Prince

Spoke to DC about discovery. He said he has confirmed there is NO footage of client in Norton whatsoever. How this is possible, I have no idea. He also stated that he is going to go back to his client and confirm, but he believes that the policies related to safety apply to every employee and each section has specific clerical policies. He said he would send over a letter expressing all of this next week.
episodes.natural_language: On July 14, 2020, in the matter of the Estate of Betty Prince, I spoke with DC about discovery. DC said that he has confirmed there is no footage of the client in Norton whatsoever, and I have no idea how this is possible. He added that he will go back to his client to confirm, but he believes that safety policies apply to every employee and that each section has specific clerical policies. He also said he would send over a letter expressing all of this next week.

episodes.natural_language:
This file, labeled Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020, concerns the Estate of Betty Prince as the client in the matter Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals, Inc., Jefferson County case number 21-CI-003798. The clients and caption are reflected in the file as the Estate of Betty Prince Premise 7/14/2020, with the Filevine project address included in thecc list. The case caption and project references indicate the litigation is between the Estate of Betty Prince and Norton Hospitals, Inc., with the Jefferson County docket number 21-CI-003798.

On June 26, 2024 at 12:56 PM, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to opposing counsel on the Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals, Inc., attaching correspondence as referenced in the message. In his signature block, he identified The Whaley Law Firm at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with the firm’s phone number (502) 365-5043 and fax number (502) 237-3207. The electronic message carried the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer, noting that it is intended only for the named recipient, may contain attorney-client privileged information, and that if received in error the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm, no waiver of privilege shall apply, and the information should not be used or forwarded to anyone else.

On Tuesday, July 9, 2024, at 4:21 PM, Bryce again wrote to counsel, addressing Ryan Nafziger and Joseph Effinger and cc’ing the Estate of Betty Prince Premise 7/14/2020 - Filevine Project Email Address, asking for an update. He indicated that he recalled discussing certain issues on the phone and had been under the impression that a more detailed explanation of the objections would follow by email, but he had not yet received it, and he requested any update.

On Wednesday, July 10, 2024, at 10:25 AM, Ryan Nafziger replied that he was still looking into the policies discussed on the phone. He confirmed that his client does not have any security footage of the plaintiff, Betty Prince, and noted that he was out of town for mediation for the next few days but would try to follow up shortly with the policies.

Finally, on the same day, July 10, 2024, at 10:26 AM, Bryce Koon responded: “Ryan, Sounds good. Thank you for getting back to me.” The July 10 message from Bryce was sent from The Whaley Law Firm to Ryan Nafziger, with copies to Joseph Effinger and to the Estate of Betty Prince Premise 7/14/2020 - Filevine Project Email Address, as well as to BettyPrinceSFZ954585@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020. Client: Estate of Betty Prince. This file contains an email chain concerning the matter Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals, Inc., Jefferson County case 21-CI-003798. The client is the Estate of Betty Prince.

The chain begins with a June 26, 2024 email from W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, directed to counsel with the line “Good afternoon counsel, Please see the attached correspondence.” The message is accompanied by the firm’s standard attorney-client privileged disclaimer, noting that the electronic message may contain privileged information and should not be used or forwarded if received in error.

On July 9, 2024, at 4:21 PM, Bryce Koon sent another message to Ryan Nafziger and Joseph Effinger (jeffinger@ppoalaw.com), with the Estate of Betty Prince Premise 7/14/2020 - Filevine Project Email Address cc’d. In this email, Bryce stated that he recalled discussions on the phone and that he was under the impression a more detailed explanation of the objections would follow via email, but he had not yet received it and asked for an update.

The following day, July 10, 2024, at 10:25 AM, Ryan Nafziger replied: he was still looking into the policies discussed on the phone and could confirm that his client did not have any security footage of Bryce’s client. He added that he was out of town for mediation for the next few days but would try to follow up shortly with those policies.

Shortly after, at 10:26 AM on the same day, Bryce Koon responded to Ryan: “Ryan, Sounds good. Thank you for getting back to me.”

On July 25, 2024, at 3:33 PM, Bryce Koon sent a forwarded message titled: “Re: Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals, Inc. (Jefferson 21-CI-003798)” to Ryan Nafziger. The forwarded message began with Bryce’s brief note: “Good afternoon Ryan, Just wanted to follow up on this. Thank you, W. Bryce Koon, Esq.” The email includes Bryce’s contact information for The Whaley Law Firm—712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207—and a confidentiality disclaimer stating that the message is intended only for the named recipient, may contain attorney-client privileged information, and that if it was received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and refrain from using or forwarding the information. The forwarded email was addressed to Ryan Nafziger and included Joseph Effinger as a recipient, with a cc to Estate of Betty Prince Premise 7/14/2020 - Filevine Project Email Address. The subject of the forwarded thread reiterates the case: Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals, Inc. (Jefferson 21-CI-003798).

In summary, the record documents an ongoing exchange between The Whaley Law Firm and opposing counsel regarding case-related policies and the presence (or absence) of security footage, with multiple dated communications from late June through July 2024 and a follow-up forwarded message on July 25, 2024.

The correspondence involves W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, and Ryan Nafziger, with the Estate of Betty Prince Premise 7/14/2020 listed in the cc as a Filevine project email address (BettyPrinceSFZ954585@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com). The matter concerns discovery issues, specifically documents about Ms. Vinson’s training as a registration clerk and related responses, with standard attorney-client privilege notices included in the messages.

On June 26, 2024, Bryce Koon sent a message to opposing counsel, stating, “Please see the attached correspondence.” The email carried the Whaley Law Firm letterhead, including the firm’s Louisville office address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with phone number 502-365-5043 and fax number 502-237-3207, and it contained the usual confidentiality and privilege disclaimer instructing that the message is for the named recipient and should not be forwarded if received in error.

On July 9, 2024, Bryce wrote again to Ryan Nafziger and Joseph Effinger (cc’ing the Estate of Betty Prince Premise 7/14/2020 - Filevine Project Email Address). He recalled a phone conversation and said he was under the impression a more detailed explanation of the objections would follow by email, but he had not received it. He requested an update.

The following day, July 10, 2024, Ryan responded to Bryce, indicating he was still looking into the policies discussed on the phone. He confirmed that his client did not have any security footage of Bryce’s client and noted he would be out of town for mediation for the next few days but would try to follow up shortly with those policies. Bryce replied, “Sounds good. Thank you for getting back to me.”

On July 25, 2024, Bryce sent another follow-up to Ryan, again requesting an update and noting that he had not yet received the requested documents or a response to his prior letter.

On July 31, 2024, Bryce wrote again with greater urgency: “Good afternoon Ryan, I still have not received any documents regarding Ms. Vinson’s training as a registration clerk or response to my previous letter. Please respond to the letter or provide the requested documents as soon as possible. If I do not receive this information promptly, I will be forced to file a motion to compel in this regard.” This message, like the others, included the standard attorney-client privilege notice and was cc’d to the Estate of Betty Prince Premise 7/14/2020 via the Filevine project email address and to the general Estate file. Ryan replied later that day, stating he was still working on the matter and trying to ensure an accurate understanding of what training Ms. Vinsom (as he spelled it) received as a registration clerk before formally answering the letter.

Throughout the thread, the subject line consistently read: “Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals, Inc. (Jefferson 21-CI-003798).” The messages reflect an ongoing dispute over discovery related to Ms. Vinson’s training and related documents, with counsel pausing to gather and verify policies and any available training records before providing a formal response.

In the Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals, Inc. (Jefferson Circuit Court, case number 21-CI-003798), the estate’s counsel, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, prepared and circulated a series of discovery and filing communications beginning in late June 2024. The case file, designated Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020, shows that the client is the Estate of Betty Prince.

On June 26, 2024, at 12:56 PM, Bryce Koon sent a message attaching correspondence related to the matter. The note included the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer common to electronic communications from the firm. The email flagged ongoing issues and served as a prelude to further discovery exchanges.

The next sequence of exchanges centers on the discovery dispute regarding Ms. Vinson’s training as a registration clerk. On July 9, 2024, at 4:21 PM, Koon wrote to Ryan Nafziger and Joseph Effinger (with a cc to the Estate of Betty Prince Premise 7/14/2020 – Filevine Project Email Address) noting that he recalled discussions by phone about the issues and that he had been under the impression a more detailed explanation of the objections would follow by email, but had not yet received it. He requested an update.

On July 10, 2024, at 10:25 AM, Ryan Nafziger replied that he was still looking into the policies discussed on the phone and could confirm that his client did not possess any security footage of the claimant. He explained that he was out of town for mediation for the next few days and would try to follow up soon with those policies. Bryce Koon responded at 10:26 AM, saying, “Sounds good. Thank you for getting back to me.” The email chain also included the standard privilege disclaimer.

Later on July 10, 2024, at 3:33 PM, Bryce Koon again reached out to Nafziger, expressing a desire to follow up on the issues and requesting an update.

On July 25, 2024, at 3:33 PM (as reflected in the chain), Bryce Koon sent another follow-up message to Nafziger requesting progress on the matter.

On July 31, 2024, at 12:53 PM, Nafziger responded that he was still working on the matter and was trying to ensure an accurate understanding of what training Ms. Vinson received while a registration clerk before formally answering the letter.

Then, on September 3, 2024, at 11:26 AM, Bryce Koon wrote again stating that he had not yet received any documents regarding Ms. Vinson’s training as a registration clerk or a response to the earlier letter. He warned that if the information was not provided promptly, he would be forced to file a motion to compel. This message also carried the firm’s privilege disclaimer.

Finally, on September 10, 2024, at 10:32:17 AM, Bryce Koon sent a message to counsel noting that the attached filing had been filed today in Jefferson Circuit Court and was set for Monday’s motion hour. The email included the same attorney-client privileged disclaimer and provided Bryce Koon’s contact information for The Whaley Law Firm at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with phone and fax numbers listed.

Throughout the thread, the participants were: Bryce Koon, Esq. (The Whaley Law Firm) as the sender in the estate matter; recipients included Ryan Nafziger and Joseph Effinger, with a cc to the Estate of Betty Prince Premise 7/14/2020 via a Filevine project email address. All emails carried the customary disclaimers regarding privilege and instructions if received in error.

In summary, the estate’s counsel pursued discovery related to Ms. Vinson’s training as a registration clerk, repeatedly requesting production of documents and clarification, while simultaneously filing and noting a matter set for motion in Jefferson Circuit Court on the pending docket of Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Hospitals, Inc.

episodes.natural_language:
In the Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020 case, the client is the Estate of Betty Prince, and the matter captioned Betty Prince v. Norton appears. On Friday, September 27, 2024, at 12:43:15 PM (GMT-04:00), W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent a message to counsel handling the Norton matter. The recipients were Joseph Effinger and Ryan Nafziger, with Andrea Higgins, Sarena Tuttle, and an entry labeled “Estate of Betty Prince Premise 7/14/2020 - Filevine Project Email Address” also copied. The message was titled “Re: Betty Prince v. Norton.” In the body, Mr. Koon wrote: Good afternoon counsel, Please see attached filed today in Jefferson Circuit Court. Thank you. W. Bryce Koon, Esq. The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Phone: (502) 365-5043; Fax: (502) 237-3207. The email carried a standard confidentiality disclaimer stating that the message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney-client privileged or protected information. It advised that if the message or any attachment was received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm, noting that no waiver of privilege applies, and that the information should not be used or forwarded to anyone not intended to receive it.

That same day, in an earlier thread, Andrea Higgins, on Friday, September 20, 2024, at about 4:54 PM, wrote to the same recipients informing them that the attached item was the service copy of Norton’s Response and Objection to Plaintiff’s Motion to Compel. Andrea Higgins identified herself as the Legal Assistant to Joseph M. Effinger, Esq., and also referenced Matthew A. Piekarski, Esq.; Ryan D. Nafziger, Esq.; and Michael J. Austin, Esq. The email provided Higgins’s contact information: ahiggins@ppoalaw.com, (502) 560-9982, and listed the office address as 716 West Main Street, Suite 300, Louisville, Kentucky 40202. It also included the firm’s main office phone number (502) 583-9900 and fax number (502) 587-1927, and the firm’s website, wppoalaw.com.

As with the September 27 email, the September 20 message carried a confidentiality notice stating that the email from Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC is for the sole use of the intended recipient(s) and may contain confidential and privileged information. The notice instructed recipients not to copy or forward the message to unauthorized persons and to contact the sender by reply e-mail or by calling the listed number to report an error if they were not the intended recipient, then to destroy all copies of the original message.

In the deposition-scheduling context for the Estate of Betty Prince v Norton Healthcare, an exchange of emails occurred between The Whaley Law Firm and PPOA Law. On December 3, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, serving as a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, wrote to Mr. Ryan Nafziger of PPOA Law (email rnafziger@ppoalaw.com) regarding the plan to depose Norton Healthcare. She stated that, at this time, their office would like to take the deposition of a Norton Healthcare corporate representative under Rule 30(b)(6). She asked Mr. Nafziger to provide the name of the corporate representative and the dates on which that representative would be available to be deposed. She also invited any questions and offered to discuss them in further detail. The message was copied to Bryce Koon (bryce@whaleylawfirm.com) and Aaron Whaley (bryce@whaleylawfirm.com)m.com) as well as Joseph Effinger (jeffinger@ppoalaw.com) and bore the subject Estate of Betty Prince v Norton Healthcare - Deposition Scheduling. In her signature, she listed her name, title, firm, and contact information: Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; Direct line 502-357-9971; Office line 502-583-4022 ext. 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating a new email address.

Two days later, on December 5, 2024, Ryan Nafziger replied. He asked whether a proposed notice for the CR 30.02(6) deposition had been sent and, if so, requested that it be resent. He also stated a desire to obtain dates for the deposition of Donna Jones at that time. The email was addressed to Sarena Tuttle and included the same CC recipients as in the prior thread: Bryce Koon, Aaron Whaley, and Joseph Effinger. The original message from Mr. Nafziger was dated Thursday, December 5, 2024, at 18:04:01 +0000, from rnafziger@ppoalaw.com to sarena@whaleylawfirm.com.

This note traces the exchange of emails regarding the Estate of Betty Prince v. Norton Healthcare and the scheduling of Donna Jones, RN, of DSJ & Associates, as a witness for deposition.

In February 2025, The Whaley Law Firm’s Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, reached out to Donna Jones, RN, of DSJ & Associates, about the Estate of Betty Prince. Tuttle reminded Jones that, in October or November 2021, Jones reviewed medical records for Betty Prince after she fell during a doctor visit at Norton Healthcare, an event that ultimately contributed to Prince’s passing. Tuttle stated that she had attached a copy of Jones’s statement for reference. With trial approaching, Tuttle explained that Jones’s deposition would need to be taken before the scheduling order was issued and asked Jones to provide dates in April when she would be available to testify. The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details listed for Tuttle were: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, D: (502) 357-9971, O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, noting the address of the new email address.

On February 24, 2025, Sarena Tuttle wrote again, this time with the subject Estate of Betty Prince v Norton Healthcare, to Donna Jones. In her message, she reiterated that Jones had reviewed the medical records related to Prince’s fall and death at Norton Healthcare in late 2021 and stated that a copy of Jones’s statement was attached. Tuttle reiterated the urgency due to the approaching trial date and again asked Jones to provide dates in April when she would be available to complete the deposition.

A separate exchange occurred on March 14, 2025. In an email to Donna Jones with the subject Re: Estate of Betty Prince v Norton Healthcare, Sarena Tuttle followed up to request the best dates and times for Jones’s deposition and asked Jones to contact the office to discuss the matter in further detail. Tuttle again provided her contact information and noted the new email address.

On March 17, 2025, Donna Jones responded. She apologized for the delay in replying and advised that her available dates for deposition were May 2, May 6, and May 8. She asked to be informed as soon as possible so she could place the deposition on the calendar. Jones also stated that the only records she possessed were Betty Prince’s records from Norton Health. If the recipient had additional records—such as Norton’s policies and procedures or any depositions taken—Jones requested that they be forwarded to her for review. She closed with thanks and respect, including her professional signature and contact information: Donna Jones, RN, DSJ & Associates, 412 Hidden Lakes Lane, Brunswick, GA 31525, donna@dsjandassociates.com, dsjandassociates.com, 404-290-2733 (cell). A standard confidentiality disclaimer followed, indicating the message was intended only for the addressees and that disclosure, use, or dissemination by others was prohibited, with instructions to destroy or delete the message and notify the sender if the recipient was not an intended addressee.

Overall, the thread shows a sequence of requests for deposition dates, with a focus on April availability initially requested, followed by Donna Jones’s later availability in early May, and a reminder to share any additional Norton Health records or depositions to aid Jones’s review.

He states that they would like to obtain dates for Norton Healthcare’s corporate representative and notes that the attached document contains the proposed deposition notice. He asks the recipient to review the attached notice and to provide dates for the corporate representative’s deposition at their earliest convenience. The email includes Mr. Koon’s contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with phone and fax numbers (Phone: 502-365-5043; Fax: 502-237-3207). A confidentiality disclaimer is included, clarifying that the message is intended only for the named recipient and that it may contain attorney-client privileged or protected information; if received in error, the recipient is instructed to contact The Whaley Law Firm, avoid waiving privileges, and not to forward the information to any unintended third party.

This thread follows earlier communications dating to December 2024. On December 3, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Mr. Ryan Nafziger requesting the deposition of Norton Healthcare’s corporate representative under Rule 30(b)(6). She asked for the name of the representative and the dates on which that person would be available to be deposed and provided her office’s contact information for discussion, including her title, office address at The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and phone numbers: D: 502-357-9971 and O: 502-583-4022 ext. 104. She signed the message as Sarena M. Tuttle and noted her new email address: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

Following that, on December 5, 2024, Mr. Nafziger replied. He asked whether a proposed notice for the CR 30.02(6) deposition had been sent and requested that it be resent if it had been issued. He also requested dates for the deposition of Donna Jones at that time. The record does not show resolutions to those requests within this excerpt, but it documents the sequence of communications aimed at scheduling these depositions.

In sum, the deposition scheduling efforts in this case span December 2024 to March 2025, revolving around obtaining a 30(b)(6) corporate representative deposition for Norton Healthcare (and the related CR 30.02(6) deposition), identifying the appropriate corporate representative, securing available deposition dates, and specifically arranging the deposition of Donna Jones, while also coordinating with counsel and providing the standard confidentiality notices customary to electronic communications among the parties.

In the Estate of Betty Prince v Norton Healthcare, captioned Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020 with the client listed as the Estate of Betty Prince, the parties were coordinating deposition scheduling for a 30(b)(6) deposition of Norton Healthcare. The communications span from December 2024 through March 2025 and involve The Whaley Law Firm and Norton Healthcare’s counsel.

On December 3, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent a message to Mr. Nafziger and Mr. Effinger, with Bryce Koon and Aaron Whaley copied, regarding the deposition of a Norton Healthcare Corporate Representative under Rule 30(b)(6) of the Kentucky Civil Rules (CR 30.02(6)). She asked Norton Healthcare to provide the name of the corporate representative and the dates on which that representative would be available to be deposed. She invited any questions and offered to discuss details further. The message included her contact information and noted a new email address: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, along with The Whaley Law Firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and the phone numbers D: (502) 357-9971 and O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104.

Two days later, on December 5, 2024, Ryan Nafziger replied. He asked whether a proposed notice for the CR 30.02(6) deposition had been sent and, if so, to resend it. He also requested dates for the deposition of Donna Jones. His message also included his contact details and a confidentiality disclaimer for The Whaley Law Firm, and it identified him as part of Norton Healthcare’s counsel.

Then, on March 3, 2025, the correspondence continued with another thread. On Tuesday, December 3, 2024 at 11:19 AM, Sarena Tuttle wrote to Mr. Nafziger and CC’d Bryce Koon and Aaron Whaley. She stated that the office wished to take the deposition of a Norton Healthcare corporate representative under 30(b)(6) and asked for the name of the representative and the available dates for deposition. She ended by reiterating her willingness to discuss any questions and provided her contact information, including her new email address.

On Tuesday, March 18, 2025, at 10:44 AM, Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, replied. He wrote, “Good morning counsel, Unfortunately, we have been unable to reach Ms. Jones for potential deposition dates. However, we would like to get dates for your corporate representative. Attached is the proposed notice in this regard. Please review and provide dates for deposition at your earliest convenience.” He signed as W. Bryce Koon, Esq., with The Whaley Law Firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and provided his phone number, Fax number, and a confidentiality notice stating the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney-client privileged information. He also noted that if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and not disclose or use any of the information.

Later that same day, at 12:48 PM, Sarena M. Tuttle responded to Counsel, providing an update. She wrote, “Good afternoon Counselors, Just an update, that we have now received dates from Mrs. Donna Jones. She is available May 2nd, 6th or 8th. Which of these dates works best for your office and Client?” Her signature line reiterated her role as Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, including the firm’s address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), direct line (D: (502) 357-9971), office line (O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104), and her email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating the email address is new.

In sum, the parties sought to schedule a deposition of Norton Healthcare’s corporate representative under CR 30.02(6), with initial requests and proposals exchanged in December 2024, and subsequent follow-up in March 2025 after obtaining information regarding Donna Jones. Donna Jones was identified as the deponent with available dates of May 2, May 6, or May 8, 2025, as communicated by Sarena Tuttle on March 18, 2025.

Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent a message to Mr. Nafziger and Mr. Effinger (with Bryce Koon copied) requesting the deposition of Norton Healthcare’s corporate representative under 30(b)(6). She asked for the name of the representative and the dates they would be available to be deposed, inviting any questions and offering to discuss them further.

Two days later, on December 5, 2024, Ryan Nafziger replied. He asked whether a proposed notice for the CR 30.02(6) deposition had been sent and requested dates for the deposition of Donna Jones at that time.

By March 25, 2025, at 10:09:25 a.m. (Eastern Time), Sarena sent another update to counsel. Case: Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020
Client: Estate of Betty Prince

Re: Estate of Betty Prince v Norton Healthcare

This matter concerns the Estate of Betty Prince and its claim against Norton Healthcare. The following email communications between Donna Jones, RN, of DSJ & Associates, and Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, relate to scheduling Donna Jones’s deposition in connection with Estate of Betty Prince v Norton Healthcare.

On February 24, 2025, at 3:48 PM, Sarena Tuttle sent an email to Mrs. Jones explaining that in October/November of 2021, Mrs. Jones reviewed medical records for the referenced client after she fell during a Doctor visit at Norton Healthcare, an event that ultimately led to the client’s passing. Sarena noted that she attached a copy of Mrs. Jones’s statement for reference. She stated that, as the trial date approached, they would need to take Mrs. Jones’s deposition prior to the scheduling order being issued and asked Mrs. Jones to provide dates in April when she would be available for deposition.

In a follow-up, dated February 24, 2025, Sarena reiterated the request for April availability and attached Mrs. Jones’s statement for reference.

On Friday, March 14, 2025, at 2:49 PM, Sarena again wrote to Mrs. Jones, asking to follow up on the request for the best dates and times for the deposition and advised Mrs. Jones to contact the office to discuss the matter in further detail. The email was sent from The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with the firm’s contact details and a note indicating the recipient should contact the office to discuss scheduling.

On Monday, March 17, 2025, at 7:32 AM, Donna Jones replied. She apologised for the delay and stated that she was available on May 2, May 6, and May 8. She asked to be informed as soon as possible so she could put the deposition on her calendar. She also noted that the only records she possessed were Betty Prince’s records from Norton Health. If there were other records (e.g., Norton’s policies/procedures or any depositions taken), she requested that those be forwarded to her for review. Her message concluded with thanks and her standard sign-off, including her contact information for DSJ & Associates at 412 Hidden Lakes Lane, Brunswick, GA 31525, donna@dsjandassociates.com, and 404-290-2733 (cell). A confidentiality notice followed, stating that the message is intended only for the addressees and may contain privileged or confidential information; dissemination or use by anyone other than the addressee is prohibited, and recipients should destroy the message if they are not the intended recipient.

The next day, Tuesday, March 18, 2025, at 12:46 PM, Sarena responded to Mrs. Jones. She thanked Mrs. Jones and said they would forward the proposed dates to the Defense Counsel to determine which date works best for all parties. She added that as soon as there is more information, they would reach out with a confirmation. This message was sent from The Whaley Law Firm and carried the firm’s updated email address, along with the standard confidentiality disclaimer.

Earlier, on Friday, March 14, 2025, the prior note in the chain from Sarena (as described above) stated the request for the best deposition dates and times and asked Mrs. Jones to contact the office to discuss in further detail.

Finally, on Wednesday, March 26, 2025, at 19:56:21 +0000, Donna Jones sent a reply to Sarena. She requested that Sarena inform her as soon as possible whether any of the dates she had provided—May 2, May 6, and May 8—would work for the deposition. Donna explained she was organizing her calendar for April and May and had several other commitments being thrust upon her. She warned that if she could not obtain timely confirmation from the defense, she would not be able to commit to the deposition until sometime in June. Donna closed with thanks for prompt assistance and her customary sign-off, followed by her confidentiality disclaimer.

Donna Jones’s contact information appeared with her signature: Donna Jones, RN, DSJ & Associates, 412 Hidden Lakes Lane, Brunswick, GA 31525, donna@dsjandassociates.com, Dsjandassociates.com, 404-290-2733 (cell). The message also included the standard confidentiality notice indicating the message is intended only for the addressees, may contain privileged and confidential information, and that any use or dissemination by non-addressees is prohibited and should be destroyed or the sender advised.

In sum, the deposition scheduling communications between Donna Jones and Sarena Tuttle circulated from February 24, 2025 through March 26, 2025, with initial deposition date requests for April, subsequent discussions of May dates (May 2, 6, 8), updates about forwarding proposed dates to defense counsel for confirmation, and a final request for confirmation from Donna about whether any of the May dates would work, given her calendar constraints and the possibility of a June deposition if timely defense feedback could not be obtained. Each exchange included a standard confidentiality disclaimer typical of the parties’ communications.

episodes.natural_language:
The Estate of Betty Prince is pursuing a case against Norton Healthcare, titled Estate of Betty Prince v Norton Healthcare, with the client identified as the Estate of Betty Prince. This note collects a series of email exchanges from late February to late March 2025 between the Whaley Law Firm, representing the estate, and Donna Jones of DSJ & Associates, regarding scheduling the deposition of Donna Jones in connection with the case. The correspondence repeatedly references the deposition dates May 2, May 6, and May 8, and notes that the deposition must occur before the scheduling order for trial is issued. The communications also mention that Donna Jones had previously reviewed medical records from Norton Health related to Betty Prince’s fall and subsequent passing, in October/November 2021, and that a statement from Donna was attached to one of the messages.

On February 24, 2025, Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm wrote to Mrs. Donna Jones, RN, at DSJ & Associates. She explained that Betty Prince’s case was approaching a trial date and that Donna’s deposition would need to be taken prior to the scheduling order. The message noted that Donna had previously reviewed Betty Prince’s medical records from Norton Health after her fall during a doctor visit, which contributed to the subsequent passing. A copy of Donna’s statement was attached for reference. Sarena requested dates in April when Donna would be available to complete the deposition.

A follow-up was sent on March 14, 2025, from Sarena to Donna Jones. The message stated, “Good afternoon Ms. Jones, We just wanted to follow up with you on our request for the best dates & times for your deposition. Please contact our office to discuss this in further detail.” The email included Sarena’s contact information and reiterated the firm’s request for available deposition dates.

On March 17, 2025, Donna Jones replied. She apologized for the delay and stated that her available dates included May 2, May 6, and May 8. She asked to be informed as soon as possible so she could place the deposition on her calendar. Donna also noted that the only records she had at that time were from Betty Prince’s Norton Health records; she requested that the Whaley firm forward any additional records to review, such as Norton’s policies and procedures or any depositions that had already been taken.

The following day, March 18, 2025, Sarena Tuttle responded. She explained that the dates Donna provided would be forwarded to the Defense Counsel to see which date works best for all parties, and that as soon as more information was available, she would reach out with a confirmation.

Later, on March 26, 2025, Donna Jones sent another message asking for a prompt determination. She reiterated the May 2, 6, and 8 dates and explained that she needed to adjust her April and May calendar due to other commitments. She added that if she could not obtain timely confirmation from the defense, she would not be able to commit to the deposition until sometime in June.

Finally, on March 27, 2025, Sarena Tuttle replied. She stated that she had already sent a follow-up to the defense and would send another one immediately, and that she would update Donna as soon as she heard back. She cautioned not to miss any commitments on their behalf and noted that if it became necessary to use the proposed May dates and push into June, they would work that out. She expressed appreciation for Donna’s assistance and did not intend to hinder her. Sarena signed the email with her position as Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm and included her new email address, Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, along with the firm’s Louisville, Kentucky office details.

The exchanges include standard confidentiality language typical of the communications, indicating that the messages contain privileged information for the addressees and should be kept confidential. The parties’ contact details appear in the signatures: Donna Jones’s information lists DSJ & Associates at 412 Hidden Lakes Lane, Brunswick, GA 31525, with the email donna@dsjandassociates.com, the website dsjandassociates.com, and the phone number 404-290-2733 (cell). Sarena Tuttle’s signature lists The Whaley Law Firm at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with the direct line 502-357-9971, the office line 502-583-4022 ext. 104, and the email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting the new address). The case documents also reference the broader legal context, including the Estate of Betty Prince v Norton Healthcare and the anticipated setting of deposition dates ahead of a scheduling order governing the trial.

In sum, between February and March 2025, the Whaley Law Firm and Donna Jones coordinated deposition availability for Donna Jones, with May 2, May 6, and May 8 identified as potential dates, while balancing the need to forward proposed dates to defense counsel and to secure timely confirmations before the scheduling order is issued for the trial. The correspondence also highlights Donna’s prior involvement with Betty Prince’s Norton Health records and requests for any additional documents to inform the deposition review, all within the framework of standard confidential communications.

In the matter captioned Estate of Betty Prince v Norton Healthcare, the case is listed as Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020, with the client identified as the Estate of Betty Prince. The original deposition-scheduling communications were conducted by The Whaley Law Firm, with Sarena M. Tuttle acting as Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager. The purpose of the email thread was to arrange depositions, including a 30(b)(6) deposition of Norton Healthcare’s corporate representative and the deposition of Nurse Donna Jones.

On December 3, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle sent the first request to counsel for Norton Healthcare, asking that Norton Healthcare provide the name of its corporate representative for a 30(b)(6) deposition and furnish dates when that representative would be available to be deposed. The message was addressed to Ryan Nafziger and Joseph Effinger, with copying to Bryce Koon, Aaron Whaley, the Estate of Betty Prince Premise 7/14/2020 Filevine project email address, and Donna Jones. The email closed with Sarena’s contact information and a note indicating her new email address.

Two days later, on December 5, 2024, Ryan Nafziger replied. He asked whether a proposed notice under CR 30.02(6) had already been sent and requested that it be resent if it had not yet been forwarded. He also requested dates for the deposition of Donna Jones, and the exchange included the same parties as in the prior message.

Fast forward to March 18, 2025, at 10:44 a.m., Bryce Koon responded to the ongoing scheduling effort. He explained that Norton Healthcare had been unable to reach Ms. Donna Jones to confirm deposition dates, but he stated a desire to obtain dates for Norton Healthcare’s corporate representative as well. He attached a proposed notice in that regard and asked that the receiving counsel review it and provide dates for the corporate deposition at their earliest convenience.

Later on March 18, 2025 at 12:48 p.m., Sarena Tuttle replied with an update regarding Donna Jones. She informed that they had now received dates from Mrs. Donna Jones, who was available on May 2, May 6, or May 8. She asked which of those dates would work best for the offices and the client.

A week later, on March 25, 2025 at 10:09 a.m., Sarena sent another follow-up. She noted that they had previously advised that Donna Jones was available on May 2, May 6, and May 8, but they had not yet received a response. She warned that these dates would likely fill up soon if a confirmation could not be provided, and she again asked counsel to confirm whether any of the dates would work for their office and schedule.

Finally, on March 27, 2025 at 1:46:56 p.m. (GMT-04:00), Sarena sent a concluding reminder. She stated that they were once again requesting confirmation or denial of Norton Healthcare’s availability for Donna Jones’ deposition. She noted that the dates Donna Jones provided—May 2, May 6, and May 8—had been shared on March 18, 2025, and that no response had been received. She requested that counsel check their calendars and respond, explaining that Donna Jones had other commitments she would like to schedule around the remaining dates. She also informed that Donna Jones had been CC’d into the conversation to facilitate the quickest reservation possible.

The communications consistently reflect The Whaley Law Firm’s efforts to schedule depositions for the Estate of Betty Prince, including the 30(b)(6) corporate representative deposition for Norton Healthcare and the deposition of Nurse Donna Jones, with ongoing follow-ups through March 2025. The correspondence includes the standard firm signature of Sarena M. Tuttle, including her phone numbers, the note about her new email address, and the firm’s Louisville, Kentucky address.

The Whaley Law Firm represents the estate, and the file header identifies the case as Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020 with the client listed as the Estate of Betty Prince. On December 3, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Mr. Ryan Nafziger and Mr. Joseph Effinger, with copies to Bryce Koon, Aaron Whaley, the “Estate of Betty Prince Premise 7/14/2020 - Filevine Project Email Address,” and Donna Jones, seeking to schedule the deposition of Norton Healthcare’s corporate representative under Rule 30(b)(6). The email asked for the name of the Norton Healthcare representative and dates on which the representative would be available, and it invited any questions and contact details for discussion. The message included Sarena’s contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line 502-357-9971; office line 502-583-4022 ext 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note stating “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

Two days later, on December 5, 2024, Ryan Nafziger replied, inquiring whether a proposed CR 30.02(6) deposition notice had been sent and requesting dates for the deposition of Donna Jones at that time.

The chain of messages also includes prior and contemporaneous exchanges. On December 3, 2024, Sarena Tuttle’s message to Mr. Nafziger—and to the same recipients mentioned above—stated the intent to take the deposition of Norton Healthcare’s Corporate Representative under 30(b)(6) and asked for the name of the representative and dates they were available, encouraging contact if there were questions and providing Sarena’s contact information.

On December 5, 2024, Ryan Nafziger’s reply asked about sending a proposed CR 30.02(6) deposition notice and requested dates for Donna Jones’s deposition.

On March 18, 2025, at 10:44 a.m., Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm wrote that Norton Healthcare had been unable to reach Donna Jones for potential deposition dates and that they would like dates for Norton Healthcare’s corporate representative; he attached a proposed notice and asked for review and the provision of deposition dates at the earliest convenience.

On March 25, 2025, at 10:09 a.m., Sarena sent another message noting that they had previously advised Donna Jones was available on May 2, May 6, or May 8, but had not received a response, and she requested confirmation whether any of those dates would work for the opposing office and scheduling.

Finally, on March 27, 2025, at 1:46 p.m., Sarena sent a further follow-up requesting confirmation or denial of the availability for Donna Jones’s deposition. She noted that the dates May 2, May 6, and May 8 had been provided on March 18, 2025, and that Donna Jones has other commitments she would like to schedule for the remaining dates. She stated that Donna Jones had been cc’d into the conversation for the quickest reservation possible.

Throughout these exchanges, the communications reflect ongoing efforts to schedule the deposition of Donna Jones—the nurse identified as Mrs. Donna Jones—and, separately, to obtain dates for Norton Healthcare’s corporate representative’s deposition under 30(b)(6). The signature blocks in these messages show the involved attorneys and staff, including Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm in Louisville, Kentucky, with the office address and contact details cited above, and Bryce Koon, also with The Whaley Law Firm, providing his contact information and confirming the firm’s representation. The email thread demonstrates a back-and-forth timeline from December 2024 through March 2025, culminating in a request for firm confirmation of Donna Jones’s availability for deposition on the specified May dates, with the understanding that Jones has other commitments and that timely scheduling is sought.

The case file Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020 concerns the Estate of Betty Prince and the matter titled Estate of Betty Prince v Norton Healthcare, specifically the deposition scheduling for Norton Healthcare. The note’s narrative begins with a Decemeber 3, 2024 email from Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, to counsel for Norton Healthcare (Ryan Nafziger, Joseph Effinger, and Andrea Higgins), with Bryce Koon, Aaron Whaley, Donna Jones, and an Estate of Betty Prince Filevine project email address cc’d. The purpose stated was to identify Norton Healthcare’s corporate representative for a 30(b)(6) deposition, including the name of the representative and the dates on which they were available to be deposed.

In that same thread, the later message from Ryan Nafziger on December 5, 2024 asked whether a proposed notice for a CR 30.02(6) deposition had been sent and requested dates for Donna Jones’s deposition. The email chain includes the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer common to these communications, and it lists the participants and contact details in the signatures. The Whaley Law Firm’s emails consistently reference their Louisville, Kentucky office at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, along with direct line 502-357-9971, main office line 502-583-4022 ext 104, and the email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, noting that it is her new email address.

On March 18, 2025, the exchange shifts to Donna Jones, a nurse, with Bryce Koon indicating that Norton Healthcare’s counsel had not yet been reached for potential deposition dates and that dates for a corporate representative deposition were also being sought; he attached a proposed notice and asked counsel to review and provide dates for the deposition at their earliest convenience. In the same exchange, the chain confirms an available schedule for Ms. Donna Jones: May 2, May 6, or May 8, 2025. Following this, Sarena Tuttle sent a message on March 18, 2025 at 12:48 PM updating that the dates for Ms. Jones had been received and asking which of the May dates would work best for the offices and the client.

Subsequently, on March 25, 2025 at approximately 10:09 AM, Sarena Tuttle sent another follow-up noting that Donna Jones had provided availability for May 2, 6, or 8, but there had been no confirmation from opposing counsel and warning that those dates could fill up quickly if not reserved promptly. The message again urged confirmation of any of those dates.

Finally, on March 27, 2025 at 2:32 PM, Sarena Tuttle addressed Andrea Higgins directly, apologizing for not having copied Andrea on the prior emails regarding the Donna Jones deposition scheduling, and requesting Andrea’s confirmation of whether Mr. Nafziger and/or Mr. Effinger would be available on May 2, 6, or 8, 2025. The email was sent with the same set of recipients and CCs as before, including the Estate of Betty Prince Premise 7/14/2020 Filevine address and Donna Jones. The thread shows ongoing efforts to schedule the depositions of Ms. Donna Jones and a Norton Healthcare corporate representative, with Donna Jones’s availability confirmed for May 2, May 6, or May 8, and the need to confirm the specific dates with the counsel representing the estate.

episodes.natural_language:
In the Estate of Betty Prince v Norton Healthcare, the client is the Estate of Betty Prince, and the case is tagged as Estate-of-Betty-Prince-Premise-7-14-2020. As part of deposition scheduling, The Whaley Law Firm’s Sarena M. Tuttle corresponded with opposing counsel and others to arrange depositions for Donna Jones, the nurse, and for Norton Healthcare’s corporate representative under Rule 30(b)(6).

The first relevant exchange occurred on December 3, 2024, when Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, requested that Norton Healthcare identify the corporate representative to be deposed under 30(b)(6) and provide the representative’s name and available dates. The email was sent to Mr. Nafziger and others, with copies to Bryce Koon, Aaron Whaley, and Donna Jones’s file-address contacts, and was part of the ongoing Estate of Betty Prince v Norton Healthcare deposition scheduling.

Two days later, on December 5, 2024, Ryan Nafziger asked whether a proposed notice under CR 30.02(6) had been sent, and he requested dates for Donna Jones’s deposition at that time.

Fast forward to March 18, 2025: Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm wrote in the morning that they had been unable to reach Ms. Jones for potential deposition dates but wished to obtain deposition dates for Norton Healthcare’s corporate representative instead. He attached a proposed notice for the corporate representative deposition and asked counsel to review it and provide dates at their earliest convenience.

Later that same day, at 12:48 p.m., Sarena Tuttle replied that they had now received dates from Mrs. Donna Jones, confirming she was available on May 2nd, 6th, or 8th, and asked which of these dates would work best for the opposing office and their client.

On March 25, 2025 at 10:09 a.m., Sarena followed up again, noting that Donna Jones had been advised as available on May 2nd, 6th, or 8th, and requesting confirmation if any of these dates would work for the opposing counsel’s office and schedule.

A further follow-up came on March 27, 2025, at about 1:46 p.m., when Sarena reiterated the request for confirmation or denial of Donna Jones’s deposition availability. She reminded that the dates had been provided on March 18, 2025, and added that Jones has other commitments she would like to accommodate, cc’ing her to ensure the quickest reservation possible.

That same day, at approximately 2:32 p.m., an additional email clarifying communication went to Andrea Higgins. In this message, Sarena apologized for Andrea not being copied on the previous chain regarding the scheduling of Donna Jones’s deposition and asked Andrea to confirm whether Mr. Nafziger and/or Mr. Effinger would be available on May 2nd, 6th, or 8th.

Throughout these exchanges, the parties repeatedly referred to the deposition of a Norton Healthcare corporate representative under 30(b)(6) and the deposition of Nurse Donna Jones, with Donna Jones’s availability stated as May 2nd, May 6th, or May 8th. The correspondence includes the Whaley Law Firm’s standard contact details, the address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, phone numbers (D: 502-357-9971; O: 502-583-4022 ext 104), and the email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting a new email address). The communications also show the chain-of-custody for Donna Jones’s deposition dates and the goal of coordinating a prompt scheduling with Norton Healthcare’s counsel and the client’s interests in scheduling around Donna Jones’s other commitments.

In sum, between December 2024 and March 27, 2025, multiple emails pursued scheduling Norton Healthcare’s corporate representative deposition under 30(b)(6) and Donna Jones’s deposition, with Donna Jones confirming initial availability on May 2, 6, and 8, and with ongoing attempts to secure firm dates and obtain confirmation from Mr. Nafziger and Mr. Effinger (and Andrea Higgins as appropriate) for those proposed May dates.
